Graphical abstract Advancements in cathode materials and emerging catalysts for Li-O2 batteries address the challenges faced by these batteries, ultimately aiming for stable operation in real-world ambient air conditions. Lithium-oxygen (Li-O2) batteries have attracted significant attention due to their ultra-high theoretical energy density. However, serious challenges, such as potential lag, low-rate capability, round-trip efficiency, and poor cycle stability, greatly limit their practical application. This review provides a comprehensive account of the development of Li-O2 batteries, elucidates the current discharge/charge mechanism, and highlights both the advantages and bottlenecks of this technology. In particular, recent research progress on various cathode materials, such as carbon-based materials, noble metals, and non-noble metals, for Li-O2 batteries is deeply reviewed, emphasizing the impact of design strategies, material structures, chemical compositions, and microphysical parameters on oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) kinetics, as well as discharge products and overall battery performance. This review will also shed light on future research directions for oxygen electrode catalysts and material construction to facilitate the development of Li-O2 batteries with maximized electrochemical performance. Keywords Li-O2 batteries Mechanism Cathode OER ORR 1 Introduction Fossil fuel is the traditional energy we mainly rely on. However, it is non-renewable and its use produces emissions of CO2, NO x , SO x , and other gases, which are the main contributors to global warming and environmental degradation [1–3]. Hence, the world currently focuses on the development of renewable energy sources and energy storage devices that are inexhaustible [4–8]. Among them, electrochemical energy storage and conversion technology have garnered a lot of attention due to their eco-friendly and high-efficiency characteristics [9–12]. Since its commercialization in the 1990 s, lithium-ion batteries have been playing a leading role in energy storage devices [13–17]. However, due to the increasing demand for higher energy density in electric vehicles, portable electronic devices, and consumer electronic products, the actual energy density of lithium-ion batteries greatly limits their widespread use. Therefore, there is a pressing need to develop new energy storage devices that can offer high energy density [18–24]. Li-O2 batteries are considered as one of the most promising options due to their extremely high theoretical energy density, which is around 9 times higher than that of traditional lithium-ion batteries (387 Wh kg−1) [25,26]. This type of batteries is composed of lithium metal anode, separator, electrolyte, and oxygen cathode. Li-O2 batteries realize the mutual conversion between electric energy and chemical energy through the reversible reaction between lithium metal, oxygen, and lithium oxide [27–29]. Li-O2 batteries can be divided into four categories according to the type of electrolyte: water system, aprotic, all solid state, and mixed aqueous/aprotic [30]. These four types of Li-O2 batteries differ in terms of their electrolyte species, which in turn dictate distinct electrochemical reactions and varying open-circuit voltages for the batteries. For instance, the open circuit voltage of alkaline aqueous electrolyte is 3.45 V [31]. Although it is higher than the open circuit voltage of aprotic Li-O2 batteries (2.96 V), the aqueous electrolytes are prone to side reactions when contacting with metal lithium, and the aqueous electrolytes decompose at low pressure [32]. For aprotic Li-O2 batteries, during discharge, oxygen is reduced through reaction with Li+ to form solid Li2O2 ( 2 L i + + O 2 + 2 e - ↔ L i 2 O 2 , E 0 = 2.96 V ), which will provide an energy density of about 3500 Wh kg−1 (based on Li2O2). Therefore, most of the research work is focused on aprotic Li-O2 batteries [33–36]. As shown in Fig. 1 , Littauer and Tsai first put forward the concept of nonaqueous Li-O2 batteries in 1976 [37]. After a span of 20 years until 1996, Abraham and Jiang reported on Li-O2 batteries with a polymer electrolyte system and proposed the discharge mechanism of 2 L i + + O 2 + 2 e - ↔ L i 2 O 2 [38]. After a decade of slow development, until Bruce et al. proved that Li2O2 could decompose during charging, Li-O2 batteries are electrochemically reversible. Since then, Li-O2 batteries have gained increasing attention [39]. However, due to the significant disparity between the theoretical capacity and actual practical capacity of Li-O2 batteries, the reasons for this gap and the reaction processes within Li-O2 batteries still require extensive exploration. It was not until 2009 that the Abraham group conducted notable research on the application of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) mechanism and the impact of aprotic electrolytes on Li-O2 batteries, Li-O2 batteries have witnessed rapid development [40]. Bruce et al. made significant contributions to the development of Li-O2 batteries. They demonstrated the use of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) as an electrolyte and a porous gold electrode, proving that the high-rate circulation process generates only Li2O2 with faster kinetics, and further proposed to use a redox mediator to effectively solve the problem of charge transfer between Li2O2 particles and the solid electrode surface during 2012 and 2013 [43,44]. The high charging overpotential in traditional Li-O2 batteries remains a challenge. Wu et al. put forward that the oxidation-reduction shuttle couples the photoelectric electrode and oxygen electrode together, reducing greatly the overpotential in 2014. This is the first unique method to integrate solar cells and Li-O2 batteries [45]. Different from traditional aprotic Li-O2 batteries, Grey et al. designed a recyclable Li-O2 battery in 2015 that could withstand high concentrations of water through the formation and decomposition of LiOH [46]. Additionally, Lu et al. predicted that LiO2 could be synthesized and stabilized in Li-O2 batteries through an electron discharge process in 2016 [47]. To comprehend the reaction mechanism of Li-O2 batteries, Luo et al. first utilized aberration-corrected environmental transmission electron microscopy (AC ETEM) to observe the morphological evolution of the product on the cathode in an oxygen environment, revealing the complete cycle reaction pathway of Li-O2 batteries by 2017 [36]. In contrast to the previous Li2O2 discharge products, in 2018, Nazar et al. developed high-energy Li-O2 batteries based on the discharge product Li2O [48]. In order to improve the severe polarization overpotential caused by the sluggish dynamics of Li-O2 batteries and the burden brought by oxygen storage accessories, Zhou et al. reported the O2-free reversible Li2O/Li2O2 conversion since 2019, which can be used to develop high energy density sealed batteries technology [49]. Due to the presence of oxygen and water in the air, traditional solid electrolytes may undergo irreversible reactions, leading to electrolyte decomposition or oxidation. Moreover, nucleation of lithium may occur within the electrolyte, potentially causing short circuits in the battery. The instability of traditional solid electrolytes in the air is not applicable to Li-air batteries. Yu et al. provided a zeolite X (LIX) membrane as the solid electrolyte of Li-air batteries in 2021. This battery has excellent electrochemical performance, flexibility, and stability, which greatly improves this defect [50]. Recently, Kondori et al. have developed a low-polarization, long-cycling room-temperature solid-state Li-air battery [51]. Similar to the findings reported by Nazar [48], it involves a four-electron reaction, with Li2O as the primary product. Although these exciting highlights show the progress of Li-O2 batteries, there are still many deficiencies which can be summarized in following four points in their practical application. (1) The current understanding of the discharge/charge reaction mechanism is not enough. A full understanding will help to solve the high specific capacity and long cycle stability of Li-O2 batteries. (2) The formation of lithium electrode dendrites can lead to short circuits in the battery, and the generation of non-decomposable discharge byproducts can cause battery deactivation. Forming a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) on the anode is an effective method to reduce these risks. (3) Since the electrolyte is unstable and easy to decompose, resulting in reduced cycle life, it is necessary to select the electrolyte with high Li+ conductivity and stability. In addition, it is urgent to look for additives that can improve the interface performance and conductivity of the electrolyte, and protect against overcharge. (4) For the cathode, it is able to provide a reaction space where the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 can occur in each cycle. Therefore, the cathode must have efficient oxygen evolution reaction (OER)/ORR catalytic performance, as well as high electronic conductivity, large specific surface and high porosity to allow for the storage of Li2O2 and the transport of O2 and Li+ which is suitable to high energy Li-O2 batteries [26,52–56]. In recent reviews, Liu et al. emphasized the elucidation of the charge-discharge reaction mechanisms in Li-O2 batteries and highlighted the challenges associated with parasitic processes occurring at interfaces of different components within the battery [54]. They also introduced several strategies to address these challenges. Kwak et al. primarily discussed the interdisciplinary aspects of materials chemistry, electrochemistry, computational methods, microscopy, spectroscopy, and surface science in nonaqueous metal-air batteries, along with recent research findings [26]. Furthermore, Lu's group, in their latest review, presented the background and historical evolution of Li-O2 batteries [57]. These reviews focused more on the challenges faced by Li-O2 batteries and provided solutions based on the battery's components (cathode, anode, and electrolyte). However, the solutions for these components are not very comprehensive, especially concerning cathode materials, which are of significant interest to the majority of researchers in the field of Li-O2 batteries. In this context, we provide a detailed description of the advancements in cathode materials and emerging catalysts. Additionally, we delve into the needed understanding for selecting these strategies to address the challenges faced by Li-O2 batteries. In this review, we first introduce the mechanism of the discharge-charge reaction of Li-O2 batteries. Secondly, according to the different compositions of cathode materials, we extensively describe the progress in electrocatalysts based on varying cathode material compositions and emerging catalysts. Furthermore, we discuss promising solutions to the main challenges of Li-O2 batteries based on oxygen electrodes of different materials, including the incorporation of cathode materials with precious metal nanoparticles, and defect engineering or functional assembly techniques to improve energy density and long-cycle stability. Finally, the future application prospect of Li-O2 batteries is introduced. 2 Mechanism for Li-O2 batteries 2.1 Fundamentals of lithium oxygen electrochemistry In aprotic Li-O2 batteries, the lithium metal anode is oxidized during the discharge process, generating lithium ions and releasing electrons. The oxygen electrode accepts electrons and O2 reacts with Li+ to form Li2O2. During the subsequent charging process, the cathode discharge product Li2O2 is decomposed into Li+ and O2, and the Li+ in the electrolyte is reduced to anode. While the anode reaction is a single electron reaction, the cathode reaction involves many complex steps and intermediates, despite it appears to be a simple two-electron reaction. Furthermore, Li2O2 is an insulator with an extremely low ionic (approximately 4 × 10−19 S cm−1) and low electronic conductivity (approximately 5 × 10−20 S cm−1), severely limiting the transit of electrons on the cathode. Additionally, Li2O2 is insoluble in most organic solvents used in electrolytes for Li-O2 batteries at room temperature. These drawbacks of Li2O2 lead to the passivation of the cathode surface in the ORR, significant polarization in the OER, sluggish the kinetics of ORR/OER and thus result in low cycling performance and poor rate capability [58–60]. It is both challenging and necessary to explore the formation process of Li2O2 to design high-performance Li-O2 batteries. Understanding this mechanism will contribute to the development of better cathode materials and improved battery performance. Herein, we will introduce the different reaction steps in Li-O2 batteries. 2.1.1 The discharge processes As shown in Fig. 2 (a), in the initial discharge reaction, O2 is adsorbed on the cathode to generate O2* (* represents the adsorbed species, Eq. (1)). Subsequently, the adsorbed O2 molecule is reduced and combined with the solvated Li+ (Eq. (2)), followed by the formation of the adsorbed LiO2 intermediate (LiO2*) through the single electron reduction reaction [61,62]. In the following reaction process, the existence of the LiO2 intermediate in different environments depends on the relative competition between the adsorption energy of the electrode material and the solubility of the electrolyte (Eq. (3)). This competition is influenced by the hard-soft acid-base theory of Pearson, which distinguishes between strong solvation of Li+ or Li+ containing species in high-donor-number (DN) solvents and weak solvation in low-DN solvents. As a result, the ORR mechanism can be divided into two modes. In low-DN solvents, a large amount of LiO2 is adsorbed on the cathode surface through a surface growth path. In contrast, in high-DN solvents, the dissolution of LiO2 in the electrolyte occurs mainly through the solution growth path. Thus, there is dissolution-adsorption equilibrium at the cathode/electrolyte interface [62,63]. Note that this equation represents the equilibrium between the adsorbed LiO2 and the LiO2 dissolved in solution (sol). For the cathode with high absorption energy in the low-DN electrolyte, the formed adsorbed LiO2 undergoes the second reduction by reacting with solvated lithium ion or the disproportionation to form Li2O2* (Eqs. (4) and (5)) [34,64,65]. Li2O2 formed on the cathode surface will be used as the nucleation point for subsequent Li2O2 growth. Typically, the final discharge product grows into a Li2O2 film on the cathode surface, which will lead to a low charge overpotential. However, in this scenario, surface passivation caused by thin films such as Li2O2 can bring about undesired premature “sudden death” and a rapid decline in both rate and capacity [61,62]. This process is described as surface pathway since the process of forming Li2O2 occurs on the cathode surface. In another case, for the cathode with low absorption energy and the electrolyte of high-DN, the adsorbed O2 − species desorb into the bulk-phase aprotic solvent to form O2(sol) −, couple with the solvated Li+ to form LiO2(sol) and further aggregate to form (LiO2(sol) n polymer. In the next step, (LiO2(sol)) n is disproportionated to Li2O2, or O2(sol) − is combined with Li+ to form Li2O2 directly through the second electronic reduction (Eqs. (6) and (7)). The subsequent Li2O2(sol) continues to grow into micron sized particles, which are randomly deposited on the cathode surface, resulting in large capacity and high charge overpotential [62]. This process is called solution pathway since the process of forming Li2O2 mainly occurs in the electrolyte. 2.1.2 The charge processes As for the charging process (decomposition process, Fig. 2b), whether this process is carried out through a single electron transfer process containing LiO2 intermediate or via double electron transfer reaction, in-situ characterization methods such as surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) were used to study this process [34,66–68]. Based on the in-situ analysis showing presence of LiO2, a single electron two-step transfer mechanism is proposed. The first step is the lithium removal process of the outer part of Li2O2 to form LiO2-like species via a solid-solution route, and the second step is the chemical process of disproportionation of LiO2 to release O2 and to generate Li+ (Eqs. (8) and (9)). The other mechanism is the direct electrochemical decomposition process with one-step double electron transfer (Eq. (10)). In contrast, due to the second mechanism occurring at high overpotentials, its kinetics is sensitive to discharge/charge rates and catalysts and can be attributed to the oxidation of bulk Li2O2 particles. Therefore, the kinetics of the first mechanism is more effective for the discharge/charge rate and catalyst than the second mechanism [36,69,70]. Among them, the morphology and crystallinity of cathode discharge products are very important to the decomposition rate of Li2O2. Although the formation and decomposition mechanism of Li2O2 is still a topic of debate, this review here prefers to present a widely accepted Li-O2 electrochemical mechanism. However, as research in this area is still ongoing, further investigation is required to gain a more in-depth understanding. 2.2 Fundamentals of photochemistry In order to improve the reaction kinetics of ORR/OER, the new type of photo-assisted Li-O2 batteries has been introduced. Its working mechanism differs somewhat from that of traditional Li-O2 batteries, primarily operating under light illumination. Photocatalysts absorb photons of appropriate energy, generating a significant number of photoelectrons and holes at specific energy levels to facilitate discharge and charge reactions [71,72]. In this regard, we provide a brief overview of the mechanism behind photo-assisted Li-O2 batteries. As shown in Fig. 3 , initially, O2 molecules diffuse through the photo-cathode and dissolve into the electrolyte. Subsequently, O2 molecules adsorbed on the photo-cathode are reduced by photoelectrons, combining with Li+ in the electrolyte. After undergoing several intermediate steps, they transform into the discharge product Li2O2. Concurrently, holes are compensated by electrons in the external circuit. During the subsequent charging process, holes oxidize the solid-state products and release O2 at a positive potential, while electrons migrate to the external circuit [73,74]. Through the photo-coupled reaction pathway, the kinetics of OER and ORR processes is significantly improved, particularly in the case of OER. Consequently, the actual charging voltage of photo-assisted batteries is substantially reduced, sometimes even falling below the thermodynamic equilibrium limit of the cell. 3 Cathode materials As the main place for the formation and decomposition of Li2O2, the oxygen electrode is the most studied part of the battery [43]. Although the development of new cathode materials is the focus of many studies, a clear classification system is still lacking. In this section, we introduce various aspects of cathode materials, including advanced preparation technology, different porous structures and specific surface areas, as well as special structures such as core-shell and heterostructures. We examine how these factors affect the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 during discharge/charge in Li-O2 batteries, and explore their influence on the electrochemical performance of the battery. 3.1 Carbon materials Because of its high conductivity, low mass density, and low cost combined with easy-to-construct porous structure, conductive carbon is one of the most attractive cathode materials for accommodating insoluble/insulating Li2O2 of Li-O2 batteries [75–78]. The low mass density and high conductivity of carbon materials are conductive to the realization of large battery capacity. Furthermore, the porous structure and specific surface area of the carbon electrode can be readily adjusted by using the existing technology in order to improve the transport efficiency of Li+ and O2 in the channel and increase the specific surface area to support the storage space of Li2O2 [79–82]. In addition, the electronic structure of carbon materials can be adjusted by introducing metal compounds, which can greatly increase the number of active sites of the catalyst and more effectively facilitate the formation and decomposition of Li2O2. Therefore, carbon materials are often applied as supporting materials because of their open porous structure [83–86]. For convenient comparison, Table 1 displayed the critical parameters of Li-O2 batteries using different carbon materials as cathodes. According to Table 1, Zhang et al. chose to incorporate Cl− into polypyrrole (Ppy-Cl); however, Li-O2 batteries exhibited poor performance due to electrolyte decomposition and the oxidation of Ppy-Cl to form numerous byproducts during discharge processes [87,88]. Zhang et al. and Shu et al. constructed N-enriched hierarchical carbon materials, which significantly facilitated Li+ diffusion and electrolyte infiltration, demonstrating excellent performance [89]. Therefore, when selecting carbon materials for electrodes, the presence of a porous structure, appropriate modifications, and the avoidance of side reactions have profound impacts on the battery performance. 3.1.1 Graphene Graphene is a two-dimensional (2D) crystal composed of sp 2 hybrid carbon atoms. Since Geim and Novoselov first stripped graphene from highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) in 2004, this novel material has been widely employed owing to its inherent excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, large surface area, significant mechanical flexibility, and high mobility of charge carriers [121]. Sun’s team first utilized graphene nanosheets (GNSs) as cathodes for non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries, which exhibited an extremely high electrochemical performance with a high specific discharge capacity of 8705.9 mA h g−1 at 75 mA g−1. Compared with the cathodes made from commercial carbon materials of BP-2000 and Vulcan XC-72 (1909.1 and 1053.8 mA h g−1, respectively), the GNSs delivered much higher capacity [90]. Meanwhile, Xiao et al. prepared functionalized graphene sheets as a cathode, which presented an astonishingly high initial discharge capacity of 15000 mA h g−1 at 0.1 mA cm−2 in Li-O2 batteries and were further tested in a pouch-type cell configuration. Besides, they confirmed that the defects and functional groups on graphene are conducive to the formation of isolated nano-Li2O2 particles on the basis of a density functional theory (DFT) calculation study [42]. The large specific surface area and high electron mobility of graphene make it a suitable cathode material for Li-O2 batteries. However, the long-term stability of graphene electrodes requires important improvement, and functionalized graphene represents an effective approach to address this challenge. Wang et al. investigated free-standing, hierarchically porous carbon derived from graphene oxide gel by a facile and effective in situ sol-gel method, wherein the proper acidity via its intrinsic COOH groups guarantees the formation of the whole structure. When it was employed as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries, the capacity reached 11060 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 (280 mA g−1) and a surprisingly high capacity of 2020 mA h g−1 can be obtained even the current density increases ten times, up to 2 mA cm−2 (2.8 A g−1) [91]. Comparably, Zhou et al. proposed a strategy of vacuum promoting thermal expansion to prepare micron scale graphene matrix with graded mesoporous/macroporous structure. Combined with subsequent deoxidation treatment, they adjusted the surface chemistry by reducing the amount of oxygen and selectively removing some unstable groups [92]. Their results indicated the unique, free-standing, hierarchically porous structure, which facilitated a continuous oxygen flow in the O2 electrode in addition to providing enough void volume for Li2O2 deposition. Although different porous graphene exhibited great potential as cathodes for Li-O2 batteries, their catalytic activity towards Li2O2 formation/decomposition is relatively low. Heteroatom-doped carbon materials have shown much better catalytic activity due to their tunable electronic structure compared to pure carbon materials. Nitrogen-doped graphene is highly attractive due to its low cost, high electronic conductivity, large surface area, and abundant surface defects. Zhao et al. designed and successfully fabricated a three-dimensional porous nitrogen-doped graphene airgel (NPGAs) framework consisting of interconnected nanocage frameworks embedded in a nanocage-tunable graphene airgel framework within a graphene sheet. The structure of graphene to achieve high specific surface area, well-developed interconnection channels, crumpled graphene sheets, and sufficient exposure of N atomic sites are shown in Fig. 4 (a and b). The as-made material demonstrates an excellent rate capacity of 5978 mA h g−1 at 3.2 A g−1, and long cycle stability of 54 cycles with a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 (Fig. 4c and d) [93]. Similarly, Xu’s group also reported nitrogen doped three-dimensional graphene (N-3DG) with numerous favorable macropores and large mesopores. When N-3DG was employed as the cathode material for Li-O2 batteries, it achieved a specific capacity of 7300 mA h g−1 and cycle life over 21 cycles than 3DG (2250 mA h g−1, 8 cycles). These good performances ascribed to the high specific surface area, well-developed interconnected channels, and exposure of N atom sites for facilitating the fast and uniform transportation of Li+ and O2 to the skeleton surface of graphene aerogels, moreover, providing a large space to accommodate the discharge products [94]. L. An confirmed through a first-principles study that boron-doped graphene reduces the rate-determining step barrier as a catalytic substrate for Li-O2 batteries, which helps increase the rate of oxygen evolution and improves the rate performance of OER [122]. In a related study, Wu et al. synthesized 3D porous boron-doped reduced graphene oxide (B-rGO) with a hierarchical structure using boron oxide generated from boric acid as a cross-linking agent and a simple freeze-drying method to maintain the structure (Fig. 4e and f). The performance of batteries with B-rGO and rGO was compared, and the results showed that the B-rGO electrode exhibited better catalytic activity, achieving a discharge capacity of 18000 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 (Fig. 4g). This is attributed to the favorable diffusion of electrolyte and oxygen within the 3D porous structure, as well as the presence of abundant functional groups and defects in the matrix, which enables a high discharge capacity and a high discharge voltage plateau. The improved catalytic performance was elucidated with DFT calculations. The binding energy of B-rGO was higher than rGO, indicating that B-rGO exhibited much stronger interaction with the Li5O6 cluster. Therefore, B-rGO expressed much more effectively activated Li–O bonds and stronger adsorption for Li2O2 than rGO (Fig. 4h) [119]. Graphene offers numerous advantages in Li-O2 batteries, including excellent electrical conductivity and high charge carrier mobility, which enhance the battery charging and discharging rates. Its large specific surface area also contributes to improved battery capacity. Additionally, graphene possesses mechanical flexibility, allowing it to accommodate volume changes within the battery. However, due to its carbon intrinsic property, graphene can undergo oxidation to produce by-products during the discharge process, necessitating improvements in its long-term stability and catalytic activity in Li-O2 batteries. To better adapt graphene for Li-O2 batteries, several strategies can be employed. These include functionalizing the graphene surface, designing porous structures to enhance oxygen transport, doping and refining synthesis methods to obtain graphene materials with superior properties. These approaches collectively aim to achieve more efficient and sustainable battery performance. 3.1.2 Carbon nanotubes Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are considered potential cathode materials for Li-O2 batteries due to their high electrical conductivity, high graphitization degree, high chemical and thermal stability, and interconnected porous structure [123–126]. Zhou’s group constructed single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) and multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) as cathodes for Li-O2 batteries. In comparison with MWCNTs, SWCNTs possessed a larger specific capacity of ∼2800 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, which is attributed to the good electronic properties and large surface area of SWCNTs [95]. Hierarchical porous electrodes comprising well-aligned MWCNTs fibrils were designed by Lim et al. Fig. 5 (a) clearly exhibits a number of micro-sized strings that compose the CNT fibril sheet and an individual string is a bundle of MWCNTs, ∼15 nm in diameter. They proved that these woven CNT electrodes can significantly enhance the cycle stability (60 cycles with the capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 2 A g−1) (Fig. 5b). Evidently, after cyclic analysis of the woven CNT air electrode, TEM images in Fig. 5(c) reveal that even under deep discharge conditions, no clogging or blocking occurred, and a uniform deposition of approximately 10 nm thick discharge product layer was observed on the surface of CNTs (as illustrated in the inset of the Fig. 5c). This was verified to be Li2O2 based on the selected area electron diffraction [127]. The above-mentioned results indicated reducing the side reactions at the carbon interface is essential, and the CNTs with much more active sites and high graphitization degree benefit from it, and therefore improve the cell’s performance. To further increase round-trip efficiency and cyclability, Shu et al. designed a 3D hierarchical bimodal mesoporous nitrogen-doped graphene/CNT composite (NGC) (Fig. 5d). As shown in Fig. 5(e), the cyclability of the Li-O2 batteries constructed with an NGC cathode was tested over 400 cycles at a fixed specific capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1 [89]. Simultaneously, DFT results were obtained based on the adsorption of LiO2 on pyrrole-incorporated graphene, pyridine-incorporated graphene, and untreated graphene. Furthermore, they presented the mechanism of the ORR in Li-O2 batteries in Fig. 5(f) from the following equations (Fig. 6 ). The high adsorption energy of LiO2 on nitrogen-doped graphene implies that the succeeding electrochemical reduction and disproportionation of LiO2 may proceed through surface diffusion and migration (Eqs. (2) and (3)). Weak adsorption of LiO2 on undoped carbon may lead to the dissolution of LiO2 and thus result in a solution reaction forming Li2O2 that can re-deposit on the cathode surface (Eq. (4)). Overall, nitrogen doping stabilizes the LiO2 relative to the undoped cathode. Stabilization of LiO2 on nitrogen-doped graphene inhibits the occurrence of nucleophilic substitution and proton abstraction side reactions between dissolved LiO2 and the solvent molecules (Eq. (5)), which is crucial to restrain the formation of side products. The morphology of (Li2O2) n is closely related to the cathode material due to the direct influence of catalyst types and structure on the generation pathway and structural distribution of discharge products. Yi et al. revealed the relationship between the growth behavior of Li2O2 on the surface of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and the cyclic performance of Li-O2 batteries based on molecular dynamic (MD) and DFT simulations. The results showed that the initial deposition of Li2O2 occurs on the surface of CNTs (Fig. 7 a), and the growth process of (Li2O2) n can be divided into three stages based on the specific deposition structures: adhesion (systems I and II), branching (systems III–V), and connection (system VI and VII). The specific distribution of Li2O2 around the CNT surface can be revealed by the relative concentration distribution as depicted in Fig. 7(b), which shows the relative concentration of (Li2O2) n around the CNT surface in three directions perpendicular to the Miller indices (100), (010), and (001), respectively. When Li2O2 is scarce, it tends to accumulate on the local surface of CNTs, and as the relative concentration curve gradually stabilizes with the increase of Li2O2 quantity, CNTs are fully covered by Li2O2 in all directions. The interaction between (Li2O2) n and CNTs was further illustrated by analyzing the total binding energy and average binding energy in Fig. 7(c), which demonstrated that armchair-type CNTs with metallic properties are more conducive to efficient electron transport. Therefore, armchair-type CNTs with larger diameters, especially SWCNTs and MWCNTs with an odd number of tube walls, are more suitable for the growth of discharge products [76]. These results elucidate the long-debated evolution mechanism of product morphology and the unique computational approach is also applicable for the intuitive exploration of the micro-growth behavior of discharge products in other metal-air batteries. CNTs possess excellent electrical conductivity, a highly graphitic structure, outstanding chemical and thermal stability, and a porous structure, all of which contribute to improved battery performance. However, CNTs have relatively low catalytic activity, limited catalytic effects on the formation and decomposition of Li2O2 in Li-O2 batteries, and interface side reactions with other battery components. Additionally, Li2O2 formation on CNTs can be unstable, affecting cycling performance. To overcome these challenges, measures such as heterogeneous atom doping to enhance catalytic activity and induce Li2O2 formation, conducting interface engineering to reduce side reactions, and optimizing CNTs performance by precisely controlling their growth conditions can be implemented. CNTs hold potential for application in Li-O2 batteries, but further improvements are needed to achieve superior battery performance. 3.1.3 Other carbon materials Although graphene and CNT have exhibited great potential as cathode materials for Li-O2 batteries, other carbon materials with uniform pores have also shown good catalytic activity. Nie et al. found micrometer-sized pores and mesopores free-standing activated carbon nanofibers (ACNF) through electrospinning combined with CO2 activation. As-prepared ACNF-based cathode behaved a specific capacity of 6099 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, and long cycle stability of 51 cycles under 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 [96]. Besides, Xia’s group also designed ordered hierarchical mesoporous/macroporous carbon (MMCSA) as a high-performance catalyst for rechargeable Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 8 a). The main pore sizes of about 3, 8, and 200 nm were synthesized (Fig. 8b and c), resulting in improved electrolyte and Li+ diffusion and electron transfer. This porous structure can provide sufficient space for O2 diffusion and O2/Li2O2 conversion. The cell exhibited a specific capacity of 7000 mA h g−1/50 mA g−1 and over 50 cycles under a fixed specific capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1 (Fig. 8d and e). Above all, the positive effect of the ordered hierarchical pore structure on the cell performance was proved by the construction of a carbon cathode [97]. Bruce et al. investigated the complex behavior of carbon electrodes in non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries using a novel approach combining with acid treatment, Fenton reagent analysis, FTIR, and in-situ DEMS (Fig. 8f–h). The results showed that hydrophobic carbon electrodes are more stable and exhibit a lower ability to promote electrolyte decomposition compared to hydrophilic carbon, possibly due to the enrichment of hydrophilic groups on the carbon surface. Furthermore, the stable cycling of Li2O2 at the cathode in Li-O2 batteries depends on the interactions between the electrode and electrolyte, rather than their individual properties [128]. Carbon materials derived from biomass have garnered significant interest as potential cathodes for Li-O2 batteries, owing to their abundance in nature and unique inherent structures. Li et al. reported Miscanthus × giganteus as a raw material for the preparation of porous activated carbon (MGACs). The MGACs-based cathode in Li-O2 batteries exhibited not only the high specific capacity of 9400 mA h g−1 at 0.02 mA cm−2 but also a long-life performance of 601 cycles under 500 mA h g−1 at 0.2 mA cm−2 [98]. These studies discuss the performance of various carbon materials as cathode materials in Li-O2 batteries, with biomass-derived carbon materials demonstrating the most exceptional stable cycling performance. This can be attributed to their large specific surface area and significant pore volume. Therefore, these results suggest that the porous structure, degree of graphitization, and surface functional groups of carbon materials play a pivotal role in ensuring the stability and performance of the battery. From the summary on carbon materials, one can note that graphene exhibits a more stable performance in Li-O2 batteries considering capacity and cycling performance. Although carbon materials hold potential as cathode materials in Li-O2 batteries, their intrinsic catalytic activity is relatively low, thus requiring specific design considerations to meet the performance requirements of the batteries. Firstly, carbon materials need to possess a uniform porous structure, which enhances the transport of O2 and Li+. Secondly, the electrical conductivity and chemical properties of carbon materials are crucial, as they directly influence the efficiency of electron transport and redox reactions. Additionally, in the design of carbon materials, it is necessary to consider how to reduce the occurrence of interface side reactions, which can lead to electrolyte decomposition and the accumulation of byproducts, thereby affecting the efficiency and lifespan of the battery. Therefore, rational functionalization of carbon materials to increase catalytic activity and reduce interface side reactions will enhance the performance and stability of Li-O2 batteries. In contrast, precious metal-based catalysts exhibit excellent electrocatalytic properties and can effectively promote redox reactions, thus having the potential as cathode materials to improve battery performance. 3.2 Precious transition metal-based cathode materials Noble metals and metal oxides, such as Au, Ag, Ir, Pt, Pd, Ru, and RuO2, have been extensively studied as potential catalysts for Li-O2 batteries, owing to their excellent catalytic performance for ORR and OER [129,130]. It is found that most noble metal based catalysts play an effective role in the formation and decomposition of discharge product Li2O2, and the performance and stability of noble metal-based cathode can be improved by changing the catalyst support and optimizing the porous structure [131]. More interestingly, Ir as a catalyst can induce the formation of stable LiO2. Ru nanocrystals as a catalyst can decompose the by-product Li2CO3, reduce the overpotential of the battery, and improve the cycle stability [47,132]. In this part, we will summarize the characteristics and performance of noble metal-based cathode. 3.2.1 Au materials In order to study the effect of cathode materials with large pore size structure on the reaction of Li-O2 batteries, Greer’s group fabricated a 3-dimensional gold micro lattice with a periodic porous structure (300 μm) and independently tunable surface composition as cathode for Li-O2 batteries. Due to the lack of carbon and chemical binders in these gold micro-lattices, it is possible to study the effect of the chemical and morphological processes on the surface of microcrystalline lattices during cycling. After the first discharge, the toroidal-shaped Li2O2 was observed covering the surface of the Au micro lattice cathode, which diminished upon subsequent charge. This work provided a useful way for investigating fundamental surface electrochemistry [133]. Peng et al. used a porous Au electrode and a DMSO as an electrolyte, this work displayed 95% of capacity retaining after 100 cycles and >99% purity of Li2O2 formation at the Au electrode. It showed that the kinetics of Li2O2 oxidation is ∼10 times faster than on carbon electrodes on charge [43]. The insulating Li2O2 of the discharge product will limit the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries while controlling Li2O2 growth is able to reduce electrode deactivation. Yang et al. reported that cracked carbon submicron tube (CST) arrays adorned with Au nanoparticles not only increase electrode conductivity and catalytic sites but also guide the growth of thin-layer Li2O2 inside the cracked CST (Fig. 9 a(i) and b). Fig. 9(a(ii) and c) showed that no large Li2O2 particles were produced after discharge and the Li2O2 conformal growth occurred on the Au@CST electrode. The Au@CST cathode was capable of performing 1208 mA h g−1 at 1000 mA g−1 and long cycle life (112 cycles at a current density of 400 mA g−1 with a limited capacity of 500 mA h g−1) [134]. Interestingly, Wang et al. designed a sandwich structure electrode composed of graphene/gold nanoparticles/gold nanosheets (G/Au-NP/Au-NS). During the discharge phase, Li2O2 exhibits a unique growth pattern, primarily initiating on the surface of gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) that are uniformly distributed between graphene and gold nanosheets (Au-NS). This controlled growth of Li2O2, constrained within the spatial and structural parameters of the Au NPs, prevents the formation of large aggregates. Li2O2 grows along the surface contours of Au NPs in an extremely thin layer, and this thin-layer structure is conducive to both the formation and decomposition of Li2O2. Additionally, during extended cycling, there is no significant accumulation of Li2CO3, and side reactions are effectively suppressed. As a result, a stable cycling performance over 300 times was achieved at 400 mA g−1 with a limited capacity of 500 mA h g−1 (Fig. 9e and f) [131]. For these two works, Li2O2 is guided to form nanoscale thin layers by Au. Furthermore, Yang et al. proved that the impact of Au coating on the adsorption behavior of Li2O2 on carbon nanotubes was confirmed through DFT calculations. It was established that the adsorption energy of Li2O2 on bare carbon nanotubes is 1.86 eV, whereas the adsorption energy of Li2O2 on Au-coated carbon nanotubes is −3.45 eV. This confirmation verifies that in the presence of Au, Li2O2 can spontaneously adhere to the carbon nanotubes. Therefore, Au plays a crucial role in guiding the growth of Li2O2 [134]. Au catalysts exhibit significant advantages in Li-O2 batteries, including outstanding redox reaction activity, rapid reaction kinetics, and their ability to guide the growth of Li2O2 while reducing side reactions. These characteristics make Au catalysts valuable for investigating the formation and decomposition processes of Li2O2, facilitating a deeper understanding of the mechanisms behind Li-O2 batteries. They also hold important potential for applications requiring high energy density and extended cycle life. 3.2.2 Ag materials The sluggish kinetics of the OER and ORR processes prevent the practical implementation of Li-O2 batteries. Xu's group conducted research on the localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) of silver nanoparticles (Ag NPs) and found that plasma thermal effects can improve the reaction kinetics of ORR and OER by reducing the reaction energy barrier and accelerating Li+ transfer. Additionally, LSPR-induced energy charges (hot electrons) injected into the O2 molecular orbitals on the surface of the nanoparticles result in the formation of O2 δ−, which then combines with Li+ to form LiO2. Upon undergoing a second electron reduction, the final product Li2O2 is formed (Fig. 10 a–c). By studying the cathode morphology and composition during discharge using SEM, it was found that a Li2O2 film of 0.2–0.3 μm cubes was formed on the surface under illumination (Fig. 10d), while fewer surface nucleation sites were observed without illumination and the size of Li2O2 increased rapidly, eventually forming a circular shape of 0.8–1 μm (Fig. 10e). The Li2O2 film had good electron transport properties and high electrochemical activity, and better complete decomposition ability compared to the circular Li2O2. Therefore, it could achieve complete decomposition at a lower charging potential, thereby improving the cycling efficiency of the battery. Furthermore, the results showed that after 400 hours of cycling in the Ag@carbon cloth (Ag@CC) battery, the increase in over-potential under illumination remained negligible, while that of Ag@CC without illumination increased from 0.789 to 1.522 V after 10 cycles, indicating excellent cycling stability of the Ag@CC cathode under illumination (Fig. 10f) [135]. To avoid the irreversible side reactions caused by carbonaceous electrodes, Lu et al. fabricated three-dimensional (3D) curved Ag/NiO-Fe2O3/Ag hybrid nanomembranes. The distinctive structure of this material provides continuous channels for the diffusion of oxygen and electrolytes, while accommodating discharge products without causing blockages. Importantly, this carbon-free nanomembrane material effectively mitigates the occurrence of side reactions, thus improving the performance of Li-O2 batteries. The battery delivered a low overpotential of 1.24 V, a high capacity of 5138 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, and long cycle life of 180 cycles at 300 mA g−1 with a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [136]. Ag catalysts can significantly enhance the kinetics of the ORR and OER in Li-O2 batteries, thereby improving battery performance. The LSPR effect endows Ag catalysts with excellent reaction activity, helping to reduce potential losses during charge and discharge processes and enhance the cycling efficiency of the battery. However, Ag catalysts also come with some potential challenges. The stability and long-term durability of catalyst surfaces require further research to ensure their stability in batteries over extended periods. 3.2.3 Ru and RuO2 materials Ru and RuO2-based materials as cathodes have demonstrated excellent catalytic activity towards both ORR and OER, resulting in a decrease in the discharge potential of Li-O2 batteries, and relative stability for long-term usage, which has attracted significant attention [137,138]. These materials are listed in Table 2 , which shows the key parameters of Ru and RuO2-based cathodes. 3.2.3.1 Ru with carbon free cathode In Li-O2 batteries, carbon and carbon-supported cathode materials are affected by negative Gibbs free energy and the discharge product Li2O2 inevitably reacts with carbon during discharge. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), isotope labeling and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMs) revealed that a single Li2CO3 molecular layer was found between Li2O2 and carbon, which could not be completely decomposed during charging. The remaining Li2CO3 accumulates and covers on the active sites of carbon, leading to large polarization and deterioration of the performance of Li-O2 batteries. To address this issue, Zhou’s group reported a carbon-free cathode which was synthesized by applying indium tin oxide (ITO) as a support of Ru nanoparticles (Ru/ITO) for the sake of avoiding Li2CO3 generation in discharge (Fig. 11b) [140]. The galvanostatic discharge-charge curves of the Li-O2 batteries with Super P Carbon black (SP), Ru/SP, Ru/ITO, and ITO as cathodes were exhibited in Fig. 11(c) at 0.025 mA cm−2. The Ru/ITO as cathode had a lower charge potential of 200 and 600 mV compared with Ru/SP and SP. The corresponding cell achieved a long lifespan (>100 cycles). After 50 charge-discharge cycles, in addition to small crystalline Li2O2 nanoparticles, similarly amorphous Li2O2 particles were found, but Li2O2 was still the main discharge product (Fig. 11d and e). Although Ru/ITO reduced overpotential and displayed long-term stability performance, the inferior specific capacity still needs to be improved [139]. In order to solve this problem, they designed Sb-incorporated tin oxide as a support of Ru nanoparticles (Ru/STO) as a carbon-free cathode for Li-O2 batteries. The Ru/STO as cathode possessed 50 cycles under a confined capacity of 750 mA h g−1 at 0.1 mA cm−2 with a low overpotential of 0.55 V (Fig. 11f and g). 3.2.3.2 Ru catalyst-based carbon materials In order to further understand how the introduced ruthenium catalyst works to improve the performance of the battery, Sun et al. synthesized Ru nanocrystal-catalyzed carbon nanotube-based aprotic Li-O2 batteries and investigated the catalytic mechanism of Ru based on a combination of Coulometry and in situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS). As a result, the battery could achieve a reduced charging overpotential of only about 0.12 V, high energy efficiency (∼85%), and long-life stability (100 cycles). The in-situ DEMS and XRD showed that Ru nanocrystals had the ability to decompose Li2CO3 at a low voltage of 3.5 V, which significantly slows down the accumulation of Li2CO3 and improved the cycle performance of the battery [132]. Similarly, Jian et al. constructed Ru nanocrystal-decorated porous graphene electrode for Li-O2 batteries, which exhibited a high reversible capacity of 17700 mA h g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1. Moreover, a low discharge/charge overpotential (about 0.355 V) and a long cycle life of up to 200 cycles (under the constrained capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at a current density of 200 mA g−1) were delivered [141]. Trees have a network of multiple transport channels for water, ions, and nutrients, Hu's group constructed a process for converting rigid and electrically insulating wood films into flexible conductive materials (Fig. 12 a). The resulting cell wall was composed of cellulose nanofibers with abundant nanopores, which were very suitable for Li+ transportation. In addition, the undisturbed wood lumen was able to act as a channel for O2 gas diffusion. As shown in Fig. 12(b and c), the continuous network of carbon nanotube interconnections on the top and inner surfaces of wood channels. As a result, the CNT/Ru-coated F-Wood cathode presented a low overpotential of 0.85 V, a high specific capacity of 7300 mA h g−1, an ultrahigh areal capacity of 67.2 mA h cm−2, a long cycling life of 220 cycles at 1000 mA g−1 with a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [142]. This group also obtained a layered porous carbon matrix by carbonization and activation of wood. The open microchannels arranged inside the carbon matrix help to facilitate the smooth diffusion of oxygen. The graded pores on the microchannel wall could be easily impregnated by electrolytes. Li-O2 batteries operate by forming Li2O2 in the cathode pores during discharge and undergoing reversible decomposition in the subsequent charging process. Electrochemical reactions take place at the two-phase or three-phase boundaries among O2, electrolytes, and cathodes, thus the performance of the battery is influenced by these boundaries [164]. Therefore, many ideal three-phase active centers were formed where electrolyte, oxygen, and catalyst accumulate on the porous wall of the microchannel. They also investigated that Ru nanoparticles were uniformly anchored to the porous wall of the carbon matrix microchannel (CA-wood/Ru) to obtain an ultrathick “breathable” wood-based cathode. The Li-O2 batteries with CA-wood/Ru cathode showed a high specific area capacity of 56.0 mA h cm−2 at 0.1 mA cm−2 [145]. When oxygen participates in the reaction in Li-O2 batteries, the interfacial interaction between catalyst and substrate is considered to be the key factor to determine the activity in different applications, the catalytic activity related to the interfacial interaction cannot thus be ignored. Shu et al. developed a Ru@hierarchically porous carbon (Ru@HPC) as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries with well-defined interfaces (Fig. 12d). Furthermore, DFT calculations revealed that the interfacial interaction between ruthenium nanoparticles and carbon matrix triggers the electron transfer of ruthenium to carbon, thereby optimizing the surface adsorption energy of reactants and intermediates, which were beneficial to improve the performance of Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 12e). The cell with Ru@HPC electrode exhibited a high specific capacity of ∼7100 mA h g−1 at a discharge/charge current density of 500 mA g−1, high round-trip efficiency of 71%. Over 125 cycles was achieved at a discharge capacity of 2000 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1 [143]. Taking a slightly different approach, Wang group loaded Ru nanocrystals on mesoporous carbon nanocubes as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries, which achieved a good cycling performance up to 120 cycles (1000 mA h g−1, 400 mA g−1) and a high electrical energy efficiency of 86.2% at 200 mA g−1 [144]. Inspired by Chinese brush painting and writing, Liu et al. prepared a paper-ink (PI) cathode (Fig. 13 a). When the paper-ink cathode was made into a collector, it was capable of replacing the traditional rigid and bulky electrode to obtain foldable highly flexible Li-O2 batteries with excellent mechanical strength and electrochemical performance (Fig. 13b and c). Low-cost flexible paper serves as the substrate for the cathode, separator, and outer packaging, enabling the assembled battery to be folded and bent. Experimental tests confirmed the mechanical stability of the PI cathode through stress-strain curve measurements, revealing its ability to withstand strains of approximately 19 MPa. Additionally, the cathode was subjected to 1000 bending cycles, and it was observed that the mechanical strength remained virtually unchanged. All of these findings demonstrate the excellent mechanical stability of the PI cathode. To further improve the electrochemical performance, Ru nanoparticles were added by a simple impregnation method. The battery equipped with a PI-Ru exhibited a cycling stability of 60 cycles at 500 mA g−1 with a discharge capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 and a lower charge overpotential than that with PI cathode. As a result, a flexible, foldable, and freestanding cathode was successfully fabricated, which effectively improved the mass-energy density and volume energy density of the Li-O2 batteries [165]. Hu et al. synthesized Ru single atoms on N-doped porous carbon through MOF-assisted space restriction and ion substitution strategy (Fig. 13d). The atomic structure was analyzed in detail by aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), revealing that an isolated Ru atom was coordinated with N or N/O species and highly dispersed in the porous carbon frame (Fig. 13e–g). The DFT results showed that Ru-N4 was the driving force center, and such configurations affected the internal affinity of intermediate species (Fig. 13h). The rate limiting step of ORR on the catalyst surface was the occurrence of 2e− for the formation of Li2O2, while the reaction of the OER pathway was the oxidation of Li2O2. Furthermore, the results of in-situ DEMS exhibited that the oxygen reduction value is 2.14 e−/O2, which means that Ru has excellent electrochemical catalytic performance. The Ru0.3 SAs-NC cathode for Li-O2 batteries illustrated the lowest discharge overpotential of only 0.17 V (Fig. 13i). This work provided effective suggestions for the rational and accurate design of monatomic high efficiency catalysts for Li-O2 batteries [146]. In Li-O2 batteries, carbon cathodes can react with Li2O2 to produce the by-product Li2CO3 at a specific potential. Li2CO3 cannot be completely decomposed during the charging stage, leading to its accumulation, increased overpotential, and a decrease in electrochemical performance. In the case of Ru-based materials, both carbon-supported and non-carbon materials have their unique advantages. Carbon-supported materials offer excellent electrical conductivity, structural stability, and abundant surface active sites, which contribute to improved battery performance. On the other hand, non-carbon materials can prevent carbon from reacting with discharge products. Although, as reported in the literature mentioned above, carbon-supported materials demonstrate significantly superior electrochemical performance compared to non-carbon materials, the choice of material still depends on battery design and specific requirements, necessitating a comprehensive consideration of these factors. 3.2.3.3 Ru catalysts supported by metal and metallic compounds In order to inhibit the side reactions to by-product Li2CO3, Liao designed a porous carbon-free catalyst by growing nanoporous Ru in a current collector of Ni foam (Ru@Ni) (Fig. 14 a). The carbon-free cathode of Ru@Ni could effectively suppress Li2CO3 generation and exhibited a specific capacity of 3720 mA h gRu −1 at a current density of 200 mA gRu −1, a long cycling life of 100 cycles at 1000 mA gRu −1 with a limited capacity of 1000 mA h gRu −1 (Fig. 14b and c) [147]. Moreover, Liu also reported a carbon-free cathode with Ru nanoparticle supported on ultralight Ni foam (UNF@Ru). The battery achieved a high specific capacity of 2410 mA h gRu −1 at 150 mA gRu −1 and a stable cycling performance for over 100 times [148]. Xie et al. used TiSi2 nanonets as conductive carriers with high specific surface area, Ru nanoparticles were deposited onto TiSi2 nanonets by atomic layer deposition to obtain a new non-carbon cathode material (Fig. 14d). It was also observed that Ru nanoparticles were selectively grown on the b-plane of TiSi2. DFT calculations showed that the selectivity was the result of different interfacial energies (Fig. 14e(i) and (ii)). As a result, the battery could be recharged more than 100 cycles with average round-trip efficiencies >70% (Fig. 14f). Above all, these studies prove that constructing carbon- and binder-free cathodes is useful for high-performance Li-O2 batteries [149]. Ru catalysts exhibit significant advantages in Li-O2 batteries, including enhanced battery performance, suppression of side reactions, versatile design approaches, and the potential for carbon-free cathodes. However, their electrochemical stability and optimization of the interfacial interaction between catalyst and substrate require further research. Future work on Ru catalysts should focus on finding suitable supports, interface engineering, and developing suitable electrolytes for Ru catalysts, among other aspects. 3.2.3.4 RuO2 materials Recently, Polyamidoamine (PAMAM) dendrimers have emerged as a template to fix nanoparticles and prevent them from agglomerating to obtain a larger specific surface area for catalysis [166,167]. Therefore, they are widely used as catalyst supports for oxygen reduction reactions. Bhattacharya et al. developed dendrimer encapsulated RuO2 nanoparticles (average 2.1 nm, DEN-RuO2) for Li-O2 batteries. The DEN-RuO2 as cathode reached a lower oxidation potential by 0.5 V in the first cycle and longer cycling life [168]. Li et al. proposed the porous RuO2 hollow spheres without any conductive agent as the carbon-free cathode of Li-O2 batteries for the first time. The results indicated a fully discharged/charged for 100 cycles, reversible specific capacity up to 1400 mA h g−1, and low overpotential of 0.68 V. The excellent electrochemical performance was attributed to the large specific surface area of hollow spheres which was conducive to the progress of OER and ORR, and facilitated the establishment of the basic two-phase and three-phase boundaries on the cathode side with impregnated electrolyte [150]. Above all, RuO2 was designed as a hollow sphere structure with a large specific surface area, which could effectively ameliorate the progress of OER and ORR, and further enhance the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries. 3.2.3.5 RuO2 materials based on CNT/Graphene The performance of Li-O2 batteries depends on the cathode reaction mechanism, the chemical structure and morphology of the reaction products, as well as their spatial and temporal evolution. Wang's group has reported the full-cycle reaction pathway of solid-state Li-O2 batteries and demonstrated the relationship between the morphology of reaction products and reaction mechanisms. Using an environmental transmission electron microscope with aberration correction, they observed the morphological evolution of carbon nanotube cathode in a working solid-state Li-O2 nanobattery under an oxygen environment and correlated these features with the electrode's electrochemical reactions (Fig. 15 a). During discharge, hollow spheres continuously grow during the ORR process, while during charge, they shrink and collapse into wrinkled shells within a few minutes (Fig. 15b). They also further verified the expansion and contraction of these hollow spheres on the cathode during battery cycling through TEM imaging. Analysis shows that the growth rate of the spheres is diffusion-limited. Furthermore, they found that the oxygen reduction reaction on CNT initially produces LiO2, which then unevenly decomposes into Li2O2 and O2. The release of O2 creates a hollow nanostructure, with the outer shell formed by Li2O and the inner shell surface formed by Li2O2 (Fig. 15c). During discharge, the diffusion of Li+, electron transport, reaction position, and adaptation to the released oxygen gas collectively determine the formation of complex morphological features. Although the morphology of discharge products is different between solid-state (hollow spheres) and non-aqueous (ring-shaped) systems, the phase of reaction products is the same for both batteries (Fig. 15d). These research results are expected to provide an important reference for the design and performance optimization of Li-O2 batteries and inspire other electrochemical catalytic reactions [36]. When the discharge product Li2O2 contacts carbon, a side reaction will occur to generate Li2CO3. In order to avoid or to reduce the CNT contact with Li2O2, Jian et al. precisely controlled a RuO2 shell to uniformly cover the CNTs core via the sol-gel method and simultaneously constructed the core-shell structure CNT@RuO2. The core-shell structure CNT@RuO2 as cathode was able to prevent large polarization and charge failure and demonstrated a low discharge and charge overpotential of 0.21 and 0.51 V, respectively, with a high round-trip efficiency (ca. 79%). The cell produced a specific capacity of 4350 mA h g−1 at 385 mA gcarbon −1 and a long stability of over 100 cycles at a high current of 500 mA gtotal −1. [151] However, low electrical efficiency limits the Li-O2 batteries electrochemical performance, to conquer this deficiency, Yilmaz et al. synthesized cathode by uniformly dispersion of RuO2 nanoparticles (RuO2 NPs) on CNTs, which achieved a higher electrical efficiency of 73% compared with pure CNTs cathode only providing 58%. As a result, this study has revealed the role of RuO2 NPs in transforming the morphology and crystal structure of Li2O2 in the nonaqueous Li-O2 electrochemical reaction. It promotes the formation of a poorly crystalline Li2O2 layer on CNTs that contains nonstoichiometry and defects. This unique Li2O2 structure provides a large contact area with the cathode and numerous defects, enabling it to decompose at lower potentials, thereby achieving high electrical efficiency. The Li-O2 batteries afforded a specific capacity of over 1800 mA h gcarbon −1 at a current rate of 0.05 mA cm−2 [152]. Instead of the core-shell structure of CNT@RuO2 made by Yilmaz et al., Zhang's group introduced RuO2 nanoparticles inside of CNT (RuO2/CNT) (Fig. 16 a). The RuO2/CNT cathode has a weak surface binding energy towards the superoxide species, which promotes the formation of LiO2, while O2 − easily diffuses to the electrolyte, promoting the solvation-mediated growth of Li2O2 during discharging and the single-electron transfer oxidation of Li2O2 during recharging, leading to the efficient formation/decomposition of the micrometer-sized flower-shaped Li2O2 assemblies (Fig. 16b). The fast formation/decomposition mechanism of these assemblies is sustainable over many cycles due to the minimal accumulation of side products on the RuO2/CNT cathode and the presence of CO2 in the electrolyte produced by parasitic electrochemistry/chemistry during Li-O2 cell cycling. The RuO2/CNT cathode also had an ultrahigh specific capacity (up to 29900 mA h g−1), relatively low overpotentials, and a long cycle life (up to 171 cycles), making it a promising material for Li-O2 batteries [34]. Huang et al. used graphene oxide as a template to synthesize two-dimensional porous RuO2 nanosheets, which were then assembled with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to form a hybrid (RuO2/CNT) with conductive porous structure and highly enhanced mass/electron transport (Fig. 16c). First-principles calculations and microscopy presented that Li2O2 strongly interacts with RuO2, following the Stranski-Krastanov growth mode thermodynamically, confirming that state hybridization converts intrinsically insulating Li2O2 into conductive, thereby reducing overshoot due to ohmic losses potential (Fig. 16d and e). This work delivered ultrahigh gravimetric energy and power densities of 1897 Wh kg−1 and 1396 W kg−1, respectively. It also exhibited cyclic stability of 224 cycles at 0.5 A gtotal −1 with a limited capacity of 500 mA h g−1 [153]. To enhance the reaction kinetics for inducing overpotential and increasing energy efficiency, Chen’s group designed 3D nanoporous nitrogen-doped graphene with encapsulated RuO2 nanoparticles. The battery presents a rechargeable capacity of 8700 mAh g−1 at the current density of 200 mA g−1, discharge/charge cycle up to 100 times at the current density of 200 mA g−1 with a limit capacity of 2000 mA h gtotal −1, and low charge potential of 3.7 V [154]. 3.2.3.6 RuO2 with metallic oxide The performance of RuO2 as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries could be further enhanced by their combination with metallic oxide. Lee et al. synthesized a RuO2/MnO2 on the CNT (RMCNT) as cathode for Li-O2 batteries that displayed 315 cycles at 1.5 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1.5 mA h cm−2. In addition, the cathode achieved reversible and energy-saving operation at high area capacity and high rate. The RMCNT air cathode with high magnification and high area capacity could provide higher power limitation of 3.0 and 4.5 mA h cm−2 for 45 and 40 cycles respectively [155]. Similarly, Zhao et al. fabricated a cathode of Mn3O4 nanowires and carbon nanotubes composite film (Mn3O4/CNTs film) with ultrafine RuO2 nanoparticles (Mn3O4/CNTs-RuO2 film) for Li-O2 batteries. The Mn3O4/CNTs-RuO2 film exhibited a capacity of 2000 mA h g−1 at a current density of 100 mA g−1. Ultra-long cycle life of 251 cycles was achieved at a current density of 200 mA g−1 with a fixed capacity of 700 mA h g−1 [156]. The outstanding performance of the battery is primarily attributed to using CNTs as the conductive matrix and scaffold, which improves the cathode's structure. Additionally, the combination of RuO2 and Mn-based oxides exhibits a synergistic catalytic effect. Yoon et al. exploited two composites of RuO2/Mn2O3 fiber-in-tube (RM-FIT) (Fig. 17 a and b) and RuO2/Mn2O3 tube-in-tube (RM-TIT) (Fig. 17c and d). In the RM-FIT, the outer Mn2O3 component catalyzes the formation of Li2O2 from Li+ and O2, but its relatively low OER catalytic activity results in insufficient decomposition of some Li2O2 on the outer surface of the RuO2 shells during charging, which affects the round-trip efficiency and performance (Fig. 17e and g). In contrast, in the RM-TIT, Mn2O3 and RuO2 nanocomposites are evenly distributed in the double-walled fibers to form a well-performing Li2O2 catalyst. During discharge, Li2O2 is mainly formed near the Mn2O3 components close to the inner and outer tubes. During charging, it is easily decomposed by adjacent RuO2 components, achieving stable cycling and high-rate performance (Fig. 17f and h). The efficient formation and decomposition of Li2O2 induced by the evenly distributed RuO2 and Mn2O3 catalysts is the starting point for stable cycling and high-rate performance in Li-O2 batteries. The RM-TIT delivered excellent bifunctional catalytic activity in RuO2 and Mn2O3, which exhibited a reduced overpotential of 1.48 V at 100 mA g−1 and stable cyclability over 100 cycles at the current density of 400 mA g−1 with a limit capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [157]. The excellent electrochemical performance can be attributed to the enhanced catalytic activity of grafted RuO2 with modulated electronic structure due to its interaction with the substrate. In Li-O2 batteries, developing catalysts with high catalytic activity and durability is crucial for improving electrochemical performance. Perovskite oxides with the general formula ABO3 are considered promising bifunctional catalysts for ORR and OER because of their low resistance, high ionic/electronic conductivity, and excellent electrochemical stability. Zhang et al. loaded RuO2 nanosheets on perovskite La0.6Sr0.4Co0.8Mn0.2O3 nanofibers as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries, which performed an astonishing specific capacity of 12741.7 mA h g−1 at a current density of 50 mA g−1 [158]. The electron metal-support interaction (EMSI) has been proposed as a criterion to Liu’s group designed and loaded with a layered porous carbon shell (FeSA-RuO2/HPCS) as an efficient and durable catalyst for Li-O2 batteries based on the criterion between metal atoms and carriers, atomically dispersed Fe-modified RuO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 18 a and b). It was found that the atomically dispersed Fe atoms formed a Ru-O-Fe1 structure with surrounding Ru sites through electron interactions, which served as a highly active driving center for oxygen reduction/evolution reactions. Specifically, the Ru-O-Fe1 structure enhanced the ORR reaction kinetics to a certain extent and optimized the morphology of discharge products by lowering the adsorption energy of the catalyst to O2 and LiO2 (Fig. 18c). In the OER process, the Ru-O-Fe1 structure not only significantly enhanced the OER reaction kinetics, but also catalyzed the efficient decomposition of the discharge product Li2O2 by facilitating electron transfer between the active sites and discharge products (Fig. 18d). As shown in Fig. 18(e), Li-O2 batteries with FeSA-RuO2/HPCS cathodes exhibited extremely low overpotential (0.34 V), and excellent durability (232 cycles). This work not only illustrated into applicability of catalysts design principle based on the EMSI criterion in the field of Li-O2 batteries, but also provides some reference value for designing catalysts with extraordinary catalytic activity and durability [169]. RuO2 exhibits excellent catalytic activity for both the OER and ORR. When designed as hollow spheres or nanosheets, it can provide a large surface area. When RuO2 is distributed on CNTs, it exhibits similar characteristics to Ru, effectively suppressing undesired side reactions on carbon materials. Furthermore, RuO2 can also facilitate the formation of a poorly crystalline Li2O2 layer. Additionally, RuO2 has a strong interaction with Li2O2, which can transform the insulating Li2O2 into a conductive material, reducing ohmic losses and greatly improving the performance of Li-O2 batteries. These remarkable performances are all based on precise design of RuO2. Therefore, in future research, a deeper understanding of the catalytic reaction mechanisms in Li-O2 batteries will be crucial to guide the development of more effective catalysts. 3.2.4 Pt and Pd as cathode materials Pt and Pd have similar characteristics, as they belong to the same group in the periodic table, have the same face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure, and possess similar atomic sizes. Due to their unique electronic conductivity and stability, they are among the promising candidate materials for Li-O2 batteries [129,170]. For Pt catalyst, the Shao-Horn group demonstrated that Pt is the most active for OER among Pt, Au, and C in bulk and nanoparticle (NP) forms, whereas Pt still has significant charge polarization due to the restricted half-filled antibonding states and weakened adsorption strength towards the intermediate species, lithium superoxide (LiO2) [171,172]. According to previous reports, changing the shape of the catalyst to adjust the arrangement and coordination of surface atoms is an effective way [173]. Another potential strategy is to embed Pt nanoparticles into porous nanostructured conductors, where uniformly distributed Pt nanoparticles can serve as electrocatalytic active sites while preserving abundant porous structures, is also an effective strategy [174]. Additionally, alloying with other metals or metal oxides to control the surface composition of catalysts is one of promising strategies to improve the activity of catalysts [175]. Song et al. compared Pt catalyst with an anisotropic structure to commercial Pt/C electrode. The battery with anisotropic Pt achieved a remarkable capacity of 12 985 mA h gcarbon −1 at a current density of 200 mA gcarbon −1, high round-trip efficiency of 87% with a low OER potential (3.1 V), and stable cyclic retention up to 70 cycles at a current density of 300 mA gcarbon −1 and a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h gcarbon −1 [176]. Through a combination of electrochemical experiments and first-principles calculations, it has been confirmed that the exceptional battery performance can be attributed to these high-index {411} facets on the surface of the anisotropic Pt catalyst. These facets exhibit a higher density of low-coordination atomic steps, such as step edges, kinks, and ledges. This not only significantly improved ORR and OER performance but also the formation of Li2O2 with unique small-sized, two-dimensional sheet-like morphology. Prior research has shown that smaller Li2O2 particle sizes (≤150 nm) lead to lower charge overpotentials and enhanced cycling efficiency compared to larger toroidal-shaped Li2O2 particles exceeding the critical size (≥1 μm) [177]. Lim et al. designed a hierarchical porous air electrode containing catalyst by cross-braiding-oriented carbon nanotubes and embedding Pt nanoparticles. The battery achieved respectable cycle stability over 100 cycles with full discharge/charge at the high current rate of 2 A g−1. This was ascribed to the insertion of the Pt catalyst, which not only greatly reduced the charge polarization but also promoted the formation of uniform thin films of discharge products [178]. In another pivotal advancement, Cao et al. introduced a UV-assisted synthesis method for preparing low-platinum content MXene-based electrocatalysts (Pt-Ti3C2) to improve the performance and reduce the cost of Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 19 a and b). The catalyst exhibits high activity and exceptional stability, demonstrating high discharge capacity, low charge overpotential, and excellent cycling performance over 100 cycles at an ultra-low platinum loading of 0.01 mg cm−2 on the cathode (Fig. 19c). This study revealed the correlation between the electrocatalytic performance and chemical microstructure, where stable Pt-Ti chemical adsorption promotes the synergistic catalytic effect of Pt nanocrystals on the multilayer Ti3C2 substrate. Furthermore, an inherent relationship was discovered between overpotential and synergistic catalysis, where the relatively gentle binding between Pt-Ti3C2 and Li2O2 monomers achieved low charge overpotential (Fig. 19d) [174]. Zhou et al. adjusted the eg occupancy rate of Pt through Pt with Au alloying to realize the charging over the potential of high-performance Li-O2 batteries. The PtAu-based Li-O2 batteries achieved a low overpotential (0.36 V) and excellent cycle life (220 cycles) at a current density of 0.1 A g−1 within a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [172]. XPS and DFT calculations revealed that the high electronegativity of Au atoms in PtAu alloys enables the capture of eg electrons from Pt atoms, resulting in a decreased population of eg electrons for Pt. This leads to the upshift of d-band center in PtAu alloys, which enhances the adsorption strength between LiO2 and PtAu, ultimately orienting the growth model of discharge products. Controlling the mesoscopic geometry of the catalyst is another effective strategy for improving the performance of Li-O2 batteries. Ryu et al. introduced the catalytic polymer-based membrane by uniformly distributing Pd nanoparticles on one-dimensional polyacrylonitrile (PAN) nanofiber scaffolds. The battery prepared in this way reduced the overpotential of 0.3 V and delivered a stable life for 60 cycles at a current density of 500 mA g−1 with a capacity of 1000 mA h g−1. The reactivity of the carbon cathode support under battery operating conditions of the battery affects the cycle performance of the Li-O2 batteries [179]. In a complementary effort, Xie et al. concealed the carbon surface to prevent contact with reactive intermediates, thus avoiding side reactions and improving the battery's cycle life. A thin layer of FeO x was grown on three-dimensional ordered mesoporous (3DOM) carbon by atomic layer deposition (ALD), and then modified with Pd nanoparticles. The cell with the cathode achieved a capacity of 6000 mA h gcarbon −1 at 100 A gcarbon −1 and cycling stability over 68 cycles at a current density of 100 mA gcarbon −1 under a fixed capacity of 500 mA h gcarbon −1 [180]. Both Pt and Pd, as catalysts for Li-O2 batteries, exhibit excellent conductivity and stability. However, their drawbacks, such as high charge polarization and weak adsorption strength toward the intermediate LiO2, have limited their performance. To address these shortcomings, researchers have employed strategies including adjusting surface atom arrangements, alloying, incorporating porous structures, and controlling electron orbital occupancy. These strategies have the potential to enhance the OER and ORR performance of Pt and Pd catalysts, demonstrating significant advantages in reducing OER overpotentials. Future research will continue to explore novel alloying strategies to improve the performance of these catalysts and compare them with other catalytic materials to better understand their competitive advantages and limitations. 3.2.5 Ir as cathode materials It is reported that Ir has a high adsorption affinity for reversible oxygen species produced in the oxidation process at a relatively low positive potential, providing excellent catalytic activity for the electrochemical oxidation reactions [181,182]. In addition to Li2O2 being a discharge product, precise design can also enable LiO2 as the discharge product. Furthermore, it is possible to design battery with O2-free reversible Li2O/Li2O2 interconversion, and all these configurations exhibit excellent performance. As described into Section 2, LiO2 as an important intermediate for Li-O2 batteries has a potentially high energy density; nevertheless, it is difficult to synthesize pure solid LiO2 because it is thermodynamically unstable and produces Li2O2 by disproportionation [183,184]. However, studies have presented that LiO2 may be formed alone on Ir catalysts in Li-O2 batteries by Lu et al. [47]. They showed that Ir/rGO can make LiO2 grow and exist stably in Li-O2 batteries. The Li-O2 batteries could repeat charged and discharged 39 times under a low charge potential of around 3.2 V (Fig. 20 a). In addition, the produced CO2 and H2 gases during charging were negligible, which proved the high reversibility of the battery containing LiO2.
