Furthermore, Ir3Li was formed as an intermediate metal compound during discharge. The formation of LiO2 could be ascribed to the similar lattice between LiO2 and Ir3Li, which could induce the nucleation and growth of crystalline LiO2. At the same time, the solvent on the surface of LiO2 was able to further inhibit the disproportionation of the crystalline phase, thus enhancing to ensure the stability of LiO2 (Fig. 20b). This new discovery is applied to synthesize stable LiO2, high energy density batteries, or other uses of the compound, such as oxygen storage. The slow dynamic barrier between gaseous O2 and solid products led to serious polarization overpotential. In addition, the gas open battery structure and the cumbrous O2 storage accessories brought additional burdens to practical applications. Zhou's group also reported Ir/rGO as the catalyst, and pre-embedded Li2O nanoparticles into it, limiting the O2-free reversible Li2O/Li2O2 mutual conversion to a sealed battery environment (Fig. 20c). Therefore, this reasonable design greatly improved the electrochemical performance of the battery. The operation of the battery depended on a single reversible Li2O/Li2O2 mutual conversion, which could effectively expand the non-oxygen evolution capacity region to 450 mA h g−1 with only 0.12 V round-trip over potential, and achieve a considerable cathode output energy density of more than 1000 Wh kg−1. As shown in Fig. 20(d), due to the different cathode structure (particle/substrate structure), the working principle here is quite different from the typical Li-O2 technology, where the Li2− x O2-Ir compound is only at the bottom (contact site) of the large ring-shaped Li2O2 particle and the O2 release tends to occur on exterior surfaces exposed to electrolyte. In addition, without any irreversible superoxide or oxygen evolution, the ultra-stable battery cycle could be realized in 2000 cycles, and the coulomb efficiency is as high as 99.5% (Fig. 20e) [49]. The instability of the carbon-based cathode and the failure of the complete decomposition of Li2CO3 produced during discharge when charging are the key problems that hinder the performance of Li-O2 batteries. Song et al. developed ultra-fine iridium modified boron carbide (Ir/B4C) nanocomposites as cathodes for Li-O2 batteries, which enabled the decomposition efficiency of Li2CO3 nearly 100% at a voltage below 4.37 V. While exposed B4C without Ir can only decompose 4.7% of the preload. The Ir-B4C based cathode could deliver 25 cycles at 10 mA g−1 under a cut-off capacity of 200 mA h g−1 with a voltage range of 2.0–4.4 V [185]. The efficient decomposition of Li2CO3 was attributed to the high affinity of Ir for oxygen species, which could reduce the energy barrier of Li2CO3 electrochemical oxidation, and has a synergistic effect with B4C. This provided a way to further develop stable oxygen electrodes and accelerate the decomposition of lithium. Ir catalysts exhibit high adsorption affinity for reversible oxygen species during the oxidation process, and intermediate metal oxides formed after coupling with rGO (Ir/rGO) can induce nucleation and growth of crystalline LiO2, enhancing the stability of LiO2. By embedding Li2O nanoparticles into it, reversible Li2O/Li2O2 interconversion with O2-free can be achieved in Li-O2 batteries, enabling highly stable battery cycling. Overall, Ir catalysts show potential in Li-O2 batteries but require further research and improvement to overcome cost and resource limitations, such as alloying Ir with other materials or designing catalysts with nanostructures to enhance performance and reduce costs. 3.2.6 Comparison of noble metals Noble metal catalysts have been proven to possess good catalytic performance in Li-O2 batteries, which can accelerate the formation and decomposition of discharge products. Therefore, it is necessary to compare their catalytic performance for the future design of noble metal electrodes. Lu et al. exploited the intrinsic ORR activity of Pd, Pt, Ru, Au, and glassy carbon surfaces in electrolyte (LiClO4 in dimethoxyethane (DME)). The results displayed that the order of Li+-ORR activity on bulk surfaces is Pd > Pt > Ru ≈ Au > GC and mainly related to oxygen adsorption energy, forming a “volcanic” trend (Fig. 21 ). This study provides an idea for designing highly active ORR surface and high discharge voltage electrode of Li-air batteries [129]. Jeong et al. also systematically studied the catalytic activity of Pt, Pd, and Ru supported on rGO for OER in Li-O2 batteries (LiCF3SO3 in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) electrolyte). All noble metal cathodes could reduce the charge overpotential; moreover, the Ru-rGO exhibited the most stable cycle performance and the lowest charge overpotential. The electrocatalysis performance of Ru nanoparticles was different from other nanoparticles. By controlling the properties of discharge products, Ru nanoparticles promoted the formation of thin film-like or nanoparticle Li2O2 during discharge, which could reduce the overpotential during charging and will keep the steady of the electrolyte [186]. In the field of Li-O2 batteries, noble metal catalysts such as Au, Ru, Pt, and Pd present unique advantages and challenges. Carbon materials (CNTs/Graphene) possess a large specific surface area and excellent conductivity, while noble metals, as efficient catalysts when supported on carbon materials, exhibit better dispersion and reduced aggregation. This combination enables batteries to operate more efficiently and effectively. Furthermore, previous reports have indicated that Au catalysts can guide the growth of Li2O2 while reducing side reactions, and Ru has the capability to decompose Li2CO3, mitigating the accumulation of Li2CO3. In carbon-free cathodes, noble metals serve as primary catalytic sites, preventing undesirable reactions between carbon and discharge products. Pt and Pd offer excellent conductivity and stability; however, they suffer from drawbacks like charge polarization and insufficient adsorption strength towards intermediates. To overcome these challenges, Guo's team adjusted the eg occupancy of Pt through alloying it with other precious metals, resulting in an upshift of the d-band center in the alloy [172]. This enhancement in adsorption strength between LiO2 and the alloy is responsible for the improved cycling performance of PtAu and PtRu compared to single precious metal catalysts. Therefore, future research should focus on novel alloying strategies, interface engineering, and the design of new porous structures to advance the application of these noble metal catalysts in high-performance Li-O2 batteries. Although noble metal-based catalysts have excellent performance in the formation/decomposition of discharge products, they are high-cost and scarce, so finding alternatives to noble metal catalysts to reduce costs is also necessary. 3.3 Non noble transition metal-based cathode materials Owing to their rich content in the earth's crust, low cost, and non-oxidizing nature with organic electrolytes, non-noble metal-based materials are considered an effective strategy to replace the noble metal-based materials. So far, non-noble metal oxides, nitrides, carbides, sulfides, and perovskites have been widely studied as cathode materials for Li-O2 batteries [187–190]. By adjusting the catalyst morphology and pore structure, more active sites and storage space for Li2O2 can be provided. These materials have good capacitance and electrochemical stability in Li-O2 batteries. 3.3.1 Cobalt oxide materials By adjusting the ratio of internal oxygen vacancy and external Co3+/CO2+ of Co3O4 nanosheets, the electrocatalytic activity of Li-O2 batteries can be improved [191]. Wang et al. confirmed the successful synthesis of Co3O4 nanosheets with this structure by Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and X-ray absorption near edge structure spectroscopy. Compared with Co3O4 bulk as a catalyst, the Co3O4 nanosheets as cathode for Li-O2 batteries exhibited a reduced overpotential, a higher discharge capacity of ∼24051.2 mA h g−1 at the current density of 100 mA g−1, better rate capability, and longer cycle life of 150 cycles at a current density of 400 mA g−1 within a limit capacity of 500 mA h g−1. The Co3O4 nanosheets with edge enriched {111} surface expose more metal atoms, which was able to effectively improve the kinetics of slow ORR and OER on the cathode. The edge enriched {111} bread contains high-density atomic steps and kinked atoms, providing a broad space for breaking chemical bonds and improving reaction activity [192]. Moreover, Liu’s team also synthesized Co3O4 nanosheets with edge enriched {111} surfaces, which can reach a high discharge capacity of 5220 mA h g−1 at the current density of 100 mA g−1 and more than 100 cycles stability as cathode for Li-O2 batteries [193]. Table 3 summarizes the comparison of the performance of Co3O4 and CoO-based cathodes. Recent studies have highlighted the significant impact of surface structures and interface interactions between catalysts and supports on performance [213,214]. Gao et al. proposed a synchronous reduction strategy to manufacture egg yolk shell Co3O4@Co3O4/Ag hybrids. Part of Ag was formed on the shell surface of Co3O4 as single atoms or clusters, and a portion of Ag was doped into the lattice of Co3O4, which not only enhances the interface bonding of Ag-Co3O4 but also adjusts the valence electron structure of Ag and Co species (Fig. 22 a–c). When Co3O4@Co3O4/Ag was employed as the cathode for Li-O2 batteries, it delivered significantly improved cycling stability of 80 cycles under 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 and an initial capacity of 12000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 than Co3O4 and Co3O4/Ag (Fig. 22d). This is attributed to the synergistic interplay of surface/interface/doping engineering within the Co3O4@Co3O4/Ag hybrid. Firstly, a portion of Ag has been doped into the lattice of Co3O4, while another fraction of Ag exists on the surface of Co3O4 in the form of single atoms or small clusters. This not only strengthens the bonding at the Ag-Co3O4 interface but also tunes the electronic structure of both Ag single atoms and Co species. The uniformly distributed Ag single atoms with adjusted electronic structure coordinately interact with Co3O4, promoting both the ORR and OER (Fig. 22e) [194]. Carbonized Co3O4 (C-Co3O4 IO) with high specific surface area and highly ordered porous inverse opal nanostructures demonstrated marvelous ORR and OER electrocatalytic activities and high energy density. Cho et al. investigated block copolymer Pluronic P123 as a template and carbon-source to construct C-Co3O4 IO via complementary colloidal self-assembly, and mixed it with commercial ketjen black (KB) machinery to obtain C-Co3O4 IO/KB. The results presented that, compared to Co3O4 nanoparticles, the C-Co3O4 IO/KB as cathode reduced the overpotential (by 284.4 mV) and increased the discharge capacitance from 3591 to 6959 mA h g−1 and circulation capacity [195]. However, carbon/Li2O2 is prone to side reactions, which hinder the performance of Li-O2 batteries. Zhang et al. proposed an effective strategy to grow core-shell Co/CoO nanoparticles on 3D graphene-coated carbon foam with 3D melamine foam as the initial skeleton (CMF-G-Co/CoO). Electrochemical and structural performance tests have indicated a synergistic effect between Co/CoO and graphene. It was observed that Li2O2 growth occurred on the surfaces of Co/CoO rather than on the carbon surfaces during the initial discharge state. This observation suggests a reduction in the carbon/Li2O2 interfaces and a mitigation of side reactions during the electrochemical process. The experimental results exhibited that the cycle life was improved to 70 cycles under 500 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and the capacity could be achieved to 7800 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1 [196]. Li-O2 batteries with cationic vacancies of Co3O4 performed a superior electrocatalytic. The formation of glycosylates composed of repeated Co-O-Co-O units provides the possibility of adjusting the ratio between cobalt and oxygen. Liu et al. prepared cobalt vacancies of Co3O4 via heat treatment of glycerol cobalt nanostructures. This battery delivered large specific capacities of 13331/12040 mA h g−1 and inferior overpotential (1.38 V) [187]. The high performance related to the electronic structure and charge transfer characteristics of cobalt oxide with rich defects improve the electrocatalytic activity. Compared with cobalt oxide cotaining Co vacancies, Gao et al. investigated the influence of cobalt oxide with integration dotted carbon species and oxygen vacancies (CoO/C) for OER and ORR. A battery based on a CoO/C electrode realized a high initial capacity of 7011 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, a much longer life of 50 cycles under 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, and a lower overpotential [197]. The enhanced performance was attributed to the synergetic effect of the dotted carbon species and oxygen vacancies on both ORR and OER. In the context of Li-O2 batteries, as catalysts, Co3O4 exhibits superior electrocatalytic activity and rate performance compared to CoO. However, it has limited capacity, which can be improved by adjusting the Co3+/Co2+ ratio, oxygen vacancies, or through strategies like doping and hybrid materials. On the other hand, CoO boasts high initial capacity and relatively long cycling life but often comes with higher overpotentials. It can be mitigated by introducing more edge sites or enhancing electron transport pathways. 3.3.2 Nickel oxide materials Ni-based current collectors are widely employed due to their higher conductivity compared to carbon current collectors. However, Ni metal is inherent susceptibility to oxidation, particularly in Li-O2 batteries systems. It has been reported that NiO not only demonstrates excellent activity in the decomposition of Li2O2, but also shows great potential in decomposition of a common byproduct of Li2CO3 in Li-O2 batteries [215,216]. Mu et al. prepared nanostructured villous foam nickel collectors with oxygen vacancies (NiO1− δ ) to construct a cathode for Li-O2 batteries, which could achieve an initial capacity of 500 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and maintain 73.5% of initial capacity after 100 cycles. The introduction of oxygen vacancies in NiO1− δ had the ability to improve the electrocatalytic activity and electronic conductivity by DFT calculation [217]. Interestingly, Wang et al. proposed another strategy to solve the slow dynamics of OER and ORR and parasitic reactions. They developed unique hierarchical NiCO2S4@NiO core-shell arrays on conductive carbon paper as a freestanding cathode for Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 23 a and b). The results exhibited a lower overpotential of 0.88 V, an improved initial capacity of 10050 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, an extremely high rate capability of 6150 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1, as well as outstanding cycle stability of 300 cycles under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 (Fig. 23c and d) [218]. This good performance could be attributed to the unique layered array structure being favorable for oxygen diffusion and electrolyte impregnation, in addition to the theoretical calculations which identified that the inherent LiO2 affinity of NiCO2S4 and NiO play an important synergistic role in promoting the formation of large particle size Li2O2 (Fig. 23e). The large charging over the potential of Li-O2 batteries has been hindering its practical application. The photo-assisted Li-O2 batteries system is an extremely effective strategy. Xu's group found a new multi-assisted Li-O2 batteries with magnetic and optical fields via preparing 3D porous NiO nanosheets on foam nickel (NiO/FNi), it can improve the photoexcited electrons and holes that are rapidly compounded during discharge and charging (Fig. 23f). COMSOL Multiphysics software was used to illustrate the distribution of the induced electromotive force generated in NiO/FNi under a magnetic field (Fig. 23g). Photogenerated electrons and holes are formed in NiO/FNi under illumination, and in the presence of the external magnetic field, both the moving electrons and holes in the magnetic field experience a Lorentz force vertical to their direction of movement (Fig. 23h). The resulting surface potential difference can be used to drive the charge separation in NiO/FNi. The magnetic and optical field multi-assisted Li-O2 batteries have extremely improved the charge potential of 2.73 V, excellent energy efficiency of 96.7%, and long-term cycle stability (Fig. 23i) [219]. The catalytic activity and electronic conductivity of NiO catalysts can be significantly enhanced by introducing oxygen vacancies and employing special structural designs such as core-shell structures. This further improves the performance of the battery. Additionally, in photo-assisted Li-O2 batteries, a well-designed NiO electrode can enhance the rate of electron-hole recombination and promote charge separation through electromagnetic forces. 3.3.3 Iron and iron oxide-based materials Transition metal-nitrogen-carbon composites prepared by the thermal decomposition of transition metals (such as Fe and Co) coordinated with nitrogen-containing organic compounds on high-surface-area carbon supports have emerged as formidable contenders to precious metal catalysts, particularly Fe-N-C, due to their outstanding ORR activity and cost-effectiveness [220,221]. Shui et al. studied the role of Fe/N/C composites in controlling the OER of Li-O2 batteries. Compared with α-MnO2/carbon catalyst and pure carbon material were used as the cathode of Li-O2 batteries to produce CO2 during discharge. Fe/N/C can only produce oxygen during discharge because it can reduce the charging overpotential [222]. Since the order in these intermetallic phases originates from the elevated enthalpy associated with mixing, they exhibit high levels of both chemical and structural stability. Goodenough’s team investigated the activity and durability of ORR of ordered Pd3Fe/C material as the cathode of Li-O2 batteries and explored the factors of the behavior of ordered Pd3Fe under annealing conditions at different temperatures. They found that the samples annealed at 600 °C were ordered Pd3Fe/C, while the samples annealed at 400 °C were disordered Pd3Fe/C. The ordered Pd3Fe/C electrode exhibited long-term cycle stability for (220 cycles) along with the overpotential only increasing from 0.9 V at the first cycle to 0.98 V at the 220th cycle [223]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as highly efficient catalysts exhibit great potential owing to the accessibility, diversity, and high microporous surface area of metal cation centers. Li et al. developed a new method for synthesizing nitrogen-doped graphene/graphene tube-rich N-Fe-MOF catalysts using polyfluoroethylene cages as templates and dicyandiamide as precursors. The graphene/graphene tube structure with high specific surface area could only be produced at the optimal temperature. They demonstrated that the catalyst exhibited excellent redox activity and improved cathode performance. The battery with an N-Fe-MOF electrode reached an initial capacity of 5300 mA h gcat −1 at a current density of 50 mA gcat −1 and a capacity loss of about 27% after the 50th cycle [224]. Furthermore, Wang et al. reported that the bimetallic organic framework (MOF, i.e. MIL-100 (FE) and ZIF-8) was thermally transformed into Fe-Fe3C embedded in Fe-N-codoped carbon as a free ORR catalyst. As a result of the rational design of the MOF, the partially graphitized amorphous carbon ensures the exposure of highly active sites. The macropores facilitate mass transfer to the catalyst surface, further enhancing the battery's performance [225]. Fe2O3-based catalyst are used in the cathode of Li-O2 batteries because of their catalytic activity, oxygen adsorption capability, and cost-effective [226]. In order to improve the poor stability and parasitic reactions related to carbon-based cathodes, Li et al. provided a cathode material composed of α-Fe2O3 nanoneedle and carbon nanotube (CNT). A cell with Fe2O3/CNT electrode delivered a discharge capacity of 805 mA h g−1 at 0.2 mA cm−2 and maintained a capacity of 1098 mA h g−1 at 0.1 mA cm−2 after 50 times full discharges (Fig. 24 a). To investigate the reason for the excellent battery performance, operando XRD showed a symmetric broadening of the (100)/(104) and (101)/(110) Li2O2/Fe2O3 lattice planes in the 2θ region of 31.5°–37° during a complete discharge and charge. The battery was (dis)charged using a 0.5 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI)/TEGDME electrolyte within a potential window of 2.0–4.5 V at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2, confirming the gradual formation and decomposition of Li2O2 (Fig. 24b). As shown in Fig. 24(c), the Li2O2 nuclei appear to nucleate on the [0 k0] surface of the Fe2O3 crystal. Since the dominant growth direction of Li2O2 is (001), and the footprint of the Li2O2 nuclei lies in the (100)/(010) direction, which matches the (104) lattice plane on the Fe2O3 surface, this supports the “epitaxially induced nucleation and growth” mechanism proposed by the authors. This mechanism has the potential to be used for controlling the growth of Li2O2, thereby enhancing the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries [227]. Photo-assisted charging can improve the high kinetic energy barrier and overpotential of Li-O2 batteries. Zhu et al. have constructed a novel S-type Fe2O3/C3N4 heterojunction and used it as an efficient catalyst for the generation and decomposition of solid Li2O2 in visible photo-responsive Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 24d). DFT simulations determined the Fermi energy level (EF) on the Fe2O3 (0001) and C3N4 (001) surfaces, which became charged in the vicinity of the Fe2O3/C3N4 interface, resulting in a huge internal electric field (IEF) that facilitates the directional migration of charge carriers through the S-type transport pathway (Fig. 24e). The unique S-type electronic transfer mechanism is reinforced by the FeN bonding at the Fe2O3 and C3N4 interface, where the enormous interfacial electric field can accelerate charge separation and significantly enhance the reaction kinetics on Fe2O3/C3N4 (Fig. 24f). This endows the photogenerated electrons on C3N4 and holes on Fe2O3 with strong redox capability, prolongs the visible light absorption and extends the lifetime of Fe2O3/C3N4, leading to significantly improved discharge voltage of Li-O2 batteries, up to 3.13 V at 0.10 mA cm−2 under illumination, as well as small overvoltage for 50 full discharge cycles at 0.40 mA cm−2 under illumination [229]. Additionally, Yu's group designed and synthesized a hierarchical TiO2-Fe2O3 heterostructure to deeply understand the mechanism of photo-assisted Li-O2 batteries. Under light conditions, photo-excited electrons participate in the reduction of O2 in the ORR process, and the holes generated are conducive to the decomposition of Li2O2 during charging. In particular, the morphology of discharge products was able to effectively adjust. Consequently, the battery achieved an ultralow overpotential of 0.19 V and maintained an excellent round-trip efficiency of ∼86% after 100 cycles [230]. Fe and Fe2O3 have significant potential as catalysts in the field of Li-O2 batteries. They not only demonstrate outstanding catalytic performance but also can suppress parasitic reactions on carbon-based cathodes, thus enhancing battery stability. However, Fe is prone to oxidation and requires thoughtful design considerations. Fe2O3 exhibits poor conductivity, which can be improved through doping and compositing with other conductive materials. Furthermore, novel approaches such as further photo-assisted charging and heterogeneous structure design offer a promising path for enhancing the performance of these catalysts. 3.3.4 Titanium oxide-based materials TiO2 with various nanostructures has received much attention. However, due to the low conductivity of semiconductive TiO2 materials, researchers have tried to combine them with highly conductive materials or produce oxygen vacancies to increase the conductivity. Kang et al. provided an electrode of black TiO2 with oxygen defects with a hierarchically ordered porous structure. The electrode featured high conductivity, micrometer-sized pores, and mesoporous walls, which could effectively tune the Li2O2 toroid and rapidly transport reactive molecules without clogging the electrode. The experimental results showed that the addition of LiI redox mediator in the electrolyte produces a very small polarization of ∼0.37 V and respectable cycling of 340 cycles (500 mA g−1, 1000 mA h g−1) [231]. In order to further design an efficient cathode catalyst for Li-O2 batteries, the method of combining DFT and the experiment was adopted by Cao et al. (Fig. 25 a and b). They prepared Ru cluster self-supporting films immobilized on the oxygen-vacancy-rich Magnéli phase Ti4O7 (Ru/Ti4O7) (Fig. 25c). A battery based on Ru/Ti4O7 exhibited a high discharge capacity of 11000 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, low overpotential of 0.36 V, and long cycle life of over 100 cycles under 200 mA g−1, 1000 mA h g−1 (Fig. 25d). The enhanced performance was attributed to the synergistic effect between Ru and Ti4O7 and the strong metal carrier interaction (SMSI) enabling a boost in the charge transfer at the interface. Besides, a flexible Li-O2 bag battery composed of Ru/Ti4O7 thin film cathode, lithium foil anode, and GPE could reach an astonishingly capacity of 5 mA h cm−2 with a low voltage gap of 0.82 V and continuously operate for 54 cycle in ambient air [232]. Since the insulating discharge product, Li2O2, is difficult to be completely oxidized by electrochemistry, an unexpectedly large overpotential will be generated. Yu et al. put forward a new strategy that the triiodide/iodide redox shuttle link to couple a dye-sensitized TiO2 photoelectric electrode with an oxygen electrode. Under illumination, the photoelectrode generated triiodide ions, which diffused to the surface of the oxygen electrode and oxidize Li2O2. The resulting photovoltage compensated for the charging voltage of the battery. The device had been determined to charge to a “negative” over potential and cycle for at least 25 cycles at 0.16 mA cm−2. This is the first time that the photoelectric electrode and oxygen electrode are coupled together, providing a unique method for the integration of solar cells and Li-O2 batteries [45]. In order to further improve the performance of photocatalysts, Tong et al. fabricated a free carbon and binder electrode (TNAs-AuNPs) coated with TiO2 nanotube arrays (TNA) and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). Under UV irradiation, Li2O2 and Li2CO3 can be effectively decomposed during discharge. The battery with TNAs-AuNPs achieved a cyclic stability of up to 200 cycles with about 100% coulombic efficiency at a current density of 333.3 mA g−1 under a fixed capacity of 500 mA h g−1 [234]. For the purpose of meeting the requirements of more convenient life applications, Zhang's team also raised a flexible porous bifunctional electrode with electrocatalytic and photocatalytic activities via in-situ growth of porous TiN/TiO2 nanowires on carbon cloth (TT@CC), which was applied to Li-O2 batteries (Fig. 25e and f). A cell with TT@CC cathode achieved an astonishing discharge capacity of 9622 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 and a long cycling test of 120 cycles at a current density of 250 mA g−1 with a cut-off capacity of 500 mA h g−1. With the help of solar energy, the cathode voltage of the battery was further reduced to 0.19 V under light, and the energy conversion efficiency reached about 94% (Fig. 25g and h) [233]. Similarly, Ren et al. designed a black TiO2 photocatalyst and carbon cloth (b-TiO2/CC) to form a photothermal synergistic multifunctional composite flexible Li-O2 batteries cathode. In the process of charge and discharge, TiO2/CC could not only generate photogenerated electrons and holes but also obtain full-spectrum sunlight. Thus, by converting solar energy into heat energy, it realized external self-heating replacement, and established a low overpotential of 0.26 V and long-term durability of up to 90 cycles at 0.05 mA cm−2 [235]. Due to the semiconductor properties of TiO2 that limits its conductivity, it hinders its performance when used directly in Li-O2 batteries. Researchers have implemented various strategies to enhance battery performance. These strategies include the creation of black TiO2 electrodes with oxygen defects, as well as innovative designs that combine photocatalytic and electrocatalytic activities, such as coupling the photoelectrode with the oxygen electrode. Additionally, the use of piezoelectric materials in Li-O2 batteries harnesses intrinsic stresses induced by the growth and decomposition of discharge products to create an internal electric field, effectively enhancing charge transfer, ion transport, and improving reaction kinetics throughout the discharge and charge cycles. This approach not only improves electrical conductivity but also greatly reduces polarization and overpotentials, significantly enhancing battery performance. These developments are crucial breakthroughs for the practical application of Li-O2 batteries. 3.3.5 Manganese oxides-based materials Based on the different connection modes of [MnO6] octahedron, the basic structural unit of MnO2, MnO2 material family has a rich crystal structure. These [MnO6] octahedral modes can share corners or edges with adjacent modes to form a complex grid, which accommodates different cations or coordination ions. Generally speaking, natural and synthetic MnO2 crystal structures have been divided into three categories, namely 1D tunnel structures (mainly including α-, β-, γ-, and ε-MnO2), 2D layered structure (δ-MnO2) and 3D network (λ-MnO2) structure [236]. Based on these aspects, the following discussion on the catalytic activity of manganese oxides was based on their different polymorphic forms, in which Table 4 summarizes the corresponding key parameters of Li-O2 batteries with typical manganese oxide materials. 3.3.5.1 α-MnO2 materials Besides the intrinsic crystal structure, the nanoscale and microscopic morphology also play critical roles in determining the electrocatalytic performance of α-MnO2. Bi et al. brought forward a 3D hollow α-MnO2 framework with a porous wall assembled by hierarchical α-MnO2 nanowires as a cathodic catalyst for Li-O2 batteries. The unique structure of the catalyst provides high catalytic activity, more catalytic active sites, a continuous hollow network, and rich porosity for the storage of discharge product aggregations and oxygen diffusion. The battery achieved an astonish specific capacity of 8583 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and long-term stability of 170 cycles at 200 mA g−1 with a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [237]. Similarly, Shen et al. prepared a series of unique three-dimensional (3D) α-MnO2/MWCNTs hybrids by a simple freeze-drying method with numerous macroporous channels interconnected in nanocomposites and manganese dioxide nanorods ranging from 100–400 nm in length and 5–10 nm in diameter. This battery exhibited a respectable discharge capacity of 8643 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and cyclic stability of over 90 cycles at 200 mA g−1 under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1. This outstanding performance is attributed to the synergy between the unique macropore structure, which provides ample space for product storage and sufficient pathways for oxygen diffusion, and the highly efficient α-MnO2/MWCNTs electrocatalyst [238]. Bruce’s group compared the catalytic activity of MnO x materials with different crystal structures and morphologies (including α-MnO2 nanoparticles, α-MnO2 nanowires, β-MnO2 nanowires, γ-MnO2 nanoparticles, Mn2O3 nanoparticles, and Mn2O3 nanoparticles) in Li-O2 batteries. They proved that α-MnO2 nanowires as cathode delivered a discharging plateau of ∼2.7 V, an impressive specific capacity of 3000 mA h g−1, and a high capacity retention efficiency of 50% after 10 cycles, which had the best catalytic activity. The outstanding performance can be attributed to the crystal structure of α-MnO2, which is hollandite and consists of 2D tunnels formed by edge- and corner-sharing MnO6 octahedra. These tunnels have the capacity to accommodate Li+ and O2 − ions, and even Li+ and O2 2− ions, which are crucial for promoting the reversibility of Li2O2 formation. This unique ability is not present in other MnO2 polymorphs or other manganese oxide materials [254]. In addition, Sun et al. also investigated the catalytic activity and stability with different crystal structures and morphologies (single crystalline α-MnO2 nanotubes, α-MnO2 nanowires, and δ-MnO2 nanosheet-based microflowers). Their catalytic activity is determined by their crystallographic structures, following the order of α->β->γ-MnO2. Moreover, in comparison to polycrystalline α-MnO2 nanowires, single-crystalline α-MnO2 nanotubes exhibit superior conductivity and possess a higher surface area, thus providing more exposed active sites to the surrounding electrolyte. Therefore, They found that the single-crystalline α-MnO2 nanotubes possessed much superior performance than other electrodes in Li-O2 batteries [255]. Yang et al. used high-energy synchrotron X-ray diffraction techniques and DFT to investigate the evolution of Li and O contents in 2 × 2 tunnels in α-MnO2 structure during cycling. The α-MnO2 cell expands and contracts anisotropically due to the intercalation/extraction reaction of Li, and the electrode particles undergo strain during cycling. When operating under oxygen, competing reactions occur between the lithium and oxygen electrodes, most notably during discharge below 2.6 V, giving the Li-O2 batteries characteristics. The synchrotron results showed no apparent evidence of crystalline Li2O2 or Li2O formation, which suggests that the α-MnO2 plays a role in the oxygen reduction reaction as the unit cell volume is relatively insensitive to oxygen content at high lithium content. This elucidated the competitive lithium insertion and lithium and oxygen insertion reactions for the formation of lithium peroxide or lithium oxide within the a-MnO2 tunnel structure. Besides, based on first-principles calculations, it was found that the sidewalls of [002] and [11 2 ¯ ] nanowires have significantly different surface oxygen densities and distributions, and thus have different catalytic activities [256]. Based on DFT calculations, Zheng et al. found that the initial electrochemical reaction between lithium atoms and surface oxygen sites can generate a potential as high as 3.4 V, which is higher than the potential for Li2O2 formation. They also described the growth process of Li2O2 on the α-MnO2 (100) surface during battery discharge, which is similar to the insertion reaction in lithium-ion batteries, but in this case, lithium ions and electrons are accommodated on the surface rather than in large intercalation layers. Therefore, surface oxygen sites are important as they serve as the initial growth points or anchoring points (Fig. 26 a). The subsequent battery potential is determined by the growth of Li2O2 itself, leading to a longer potential plateau in the discharge curve. They predicted that metal oxide nanowires grown along the [001] direction should have the best catalytic activity for Li-O2 batteries because they have the highest surface oxygen density and are uniformly distributed on the side walls, which is a result of their preferred surface (Fig. 26b and c). The [002] oriented α-MnO2 nanowires and [11 2 ¯ ] oriented α-MnO2 nanowires were successfully synthesized (Fig. 26d and e). The experimental results exhibited that [002] oriented α-MnO2 nanowires have better catalytic activity, confirming that oxygen sites on the cathode surface play a more important role than exposed metal sites (Fig. 26f) [239]. 3.3.5.2 δ-MnO2 materials Different from the chain tunnel structure of other MnO2 polymorphs, the crystal structure of δ-MnO2 is a layered structure with a larger specific surface area. Liu et al. investigated the oxygen reduction mechanism of δ-MnO2 monolayers and the conditions for Li2O2 growth via first-principles calculations and mesoscopic modeling. Based on the evaluation of adsorption energies, it was found that MnO2 monolayers prefer to react with Li atoms rather than O2 molecules to initiate LiO2 formation and have a strong affinity for LiO2 and Li2O2 species, which contributes to the formation of wetting Li2O2 film on the cathode surface. In addition, the formation of Li2O2 only requires overpotential of 0.49 V compared to the formation of Li2O during the discharge process, so it can be predicted that Li2O2 is the main discharge product. Electronic structure studies further reveal that the interfacial phase is metal and thus can facilitate charge transport. Based on the parameters derived from DFT, a mesoscopic Kinetic Monte Carlo model was established to study the effects of applied potential and temperature on the reaction kinetics of the δ-MnO2 surface. The results showed that the formation of Li2O2 is sensitive to the applied potential. When the applied potential is lower than 2.4 V, the electrochemical reaction plays a major role in the formation of Li2O2 [257]. Liu et al. prepared a binder-free air electrode composed of 3D graphene and flower-like δ-MnO2. The flower-like δ-MnO2 exhibited high ORR and OER catalytic activity while the unique 3D scaffold structure of 3D-G-MnO2 electrode facilitates O2 diffusion and electrode wetting. The battery achieved an initial specific capacity of 3660 mA h g−1 at 0.083 mA cm−2 with a high discharge plateau of around 2.8 V, and a stable long-term life of 132 cycles at 0.333 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 492 mA h g−1 [240]. As a complementary approach, Ma et al. also prepared composite catalysts that contributed to the adsorption of O2 by synthesizing δ-MnO2@MWCNTs and retaining the high specific surface area and abundant mesoporous structure of MWCNTs, which exhibited excellent performance with a high specific capacity of 28517 mA h g−1 (100 mA g−1), a high rate performance of 75% initial specific capacity (1000 mA g−1), and respectable cycling of 190 cycles (1000 mA h g−1, 100 mA g−1) [241]. 3.3.5.3 Other MnO2 materials Suib and co-workers used titanium cations as structure-directing agents to synthesize titanium-containing γ-MnO2 octahedral molecular sieves with hollow sphere structures in a one-step method. Ti-doped γ-MnO2 demonstrates excellent electrocatalytic activity for O2 reduction, thus the battery with Ti-doped γ-MnO2 produced a high discharge capacity of up to 2300 mA h g−1 [258]. Different from traditional aprotic Li-O2 batteries, Zhou's group reported a reaction mechanism at the cathode, catalyzing the cathode reactions of Li-O2 batteries during discharge and charge by applying a trace amount of water in the electrolyte. By using Ru/γ-MnO2/carbon black Super P as the cathode for Li-O2 batteries, adding a small amount of water to the electrolyte, and Li+ ion-conducting ceramic membrane separating the electrolyte with water and Li anode, they found that chemically active Li2O2 was converted into LiOH during discharge to alleviate carbon related side reactions (Fig. 27 a). The results achieved that the charge overpotential was significantly reduced to 0.21 V, and resulted in a small discharge/charge potential gap of 0.32 V and long lifespan stability of 200 cycles at 500 mA g−1 with a controlled capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 (Fig. 27b and c) [242]. Hu et al. reported spongy ε-MnO2 nanostructures were able to directly grow ε-MnO2 on foam nickel by a simple electrodeposition method. It could be directly used as a carbon-free and binder-free cathode of Li-O2 batteries, which can effectively prevent side reactions and reducing overpotential. The battery with ε-MnO2 electrode delivered a high-rate specific capacity of ∼6300 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1 and excellent electrochemical reversibility of 120 cycles without controlling the discharge depth [243]. Meanwhile, they also grew hierarchical porous ε-MnO2 (OTM) on nickel foam via electrodeposition as a carbon-free cathode, which possessed a specific discharge capacity of 5700 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and a long lifespan of 190 cycles under 800 mA h g−1 (500 mA g−1) [244]. Based on the research described above, it can be conclusively demonstrated that MnO2, as a cathode, can effectively promote the reversible formation and decomposition of Li2O2 while reducing overpotentials. However, its catalytic activity is greatly influenced by factors such as crystal structure, morphology, size, pore structure, manganese atom surface oxidation states, and surface oxygen density. From the current research results, the α-phase MnO2 with a hollandite structure stands out due to its unique crystal structure, exhibiting superior catalytic characteristics compared to other MnO2 phases. Furthermore, even for MnO2 materials with the same crystal structure, different morphologies can have a significant impact on MnO2. To mass-produce high-performance MnO2 catalysts, it is necessary to optimize the synthesis conditions to achieve large-scale production of high-purity MnO2 with ideal morphologies. 3.3.6 Binary metal oxides materials Peng et al. designed a simple solvothermal method that could be used to synthesize three-dimensional hierarchical spinel core-shell microspheres with porous structures, such as NiCO2O4, MnCO2O4, and ZnCO2O4. This unique structure provides a larger reaction area for nucleation or accommodation of Li2O2, while also offering more electrocatalytic sites, resulting in a higher specific capacity. The mesopores within the nanoplates facilitate the flow of oxygen and the infiltration of the electrolyte. NiCO2O4 was applied as the cathode of Li-O2 batteries achieved a specific capacity of 8658 mA h gcarbon −1 at 100 mA gcarbon −1, and a long-term stability cycling of over 128 cycles at 200 mA gcarbon −1 under a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h gcarbon −1 [259]. Similarly, Liu et al. synthesized NiCO2O4 particles with sizes ranging from 20–30 nm to ∼2 nm uniformly distributed via an electrochemical prelithiation process, and this structure remained stable in long-term cycling, thus showing remarkable OER/ORR catalytic effect. The battery exhibited a considerable specific discharge capacity of 29280 mA h g−1 and maintained a capacity of over 1000 mA h g−1 at 100 cycles at 0.1 mA cm−2 [260]. Furthermore, Wu et al. fabricated the composite microsphere material NiCO2O4@CeO2 by hydrothermal method to improve the large overpotential. The unique microstructure provided sufficient catalytic surface, and the introduction of CeO2 could increase oxygen vacancies and optimize the electronic structure of NiCO2O4. Notably, the electrochemical performance of NiCO2O4@CeO2, NiCO2O4, CeO2, and pure CNTs electrodes in Li-O2 batteries were compared, the NiCO2O4@CeO2 electrode possessed an ultra-low overpotential of 1.07 V, an initial specific discharge capacity of 5586 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1, and a long lifespan cycling of 400 cycles at 500 mA g−1 with a controlled capacity of 500 mA h g−1 [261]. Dai's team reported that the MnCO2O4-graphene hybrid material exhibited strong covalent coupling between the oxide nanoparticles and the conductive graphene substrate through the direct nucleation and growth of MnCO2O4 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide. This effective interaction within the hybrid structure facilitates the rapid and efficient transfer of electrons on the conductive graphene, thereby promoting the catalysis of the charging and discharging reactions on the surface of the oxide nanoparticles. The battery based on MnCO2O4-graphene hybrid achieved a specific initial discharge capacity of ∼3784 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and stable cycle life of more than 20 cycles under a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [262]. In a related study, Cao et al. demonstrated the controllable modulation of the crystal phase of Mn x Co1− x O catalysts by adjusting the cation molar ratio via a hydrothermal method (Fig. 28 a). It was found that Mn x Co1− x O catalysts underwent specific structural evolution as the Mn/Co ratio increased from 1/9 to 9/1, which optimized the material's electrical and catalytic properties (Fig. 28b–e). In particular, when the Mn/Co molar ratio was 8/2, the Mn x Co1− x O catalyst exhibited a significantly reduced charge overpotential (only 0.48 V), which was a significant advantage (Fig. 28f). In addition, DFT calculations revealed the correlation between different forms of Li2O2 and the electronic conductivity and binding energy of Mn x Co1− x O crystal surfaces, ultimately leading to different charge overpotentials (Fig. 28g) [263]. Octahedral spinel provides a stable polycrystalline structure and optimized electronic structure together with dominating the evolution of discharge/charging products at low/high rates. He et al. proposed a modified three-dimensional structure NiFeO cubic spinel with cation occupation via super assembly strategy, which greatly remedies the catalytic activity. The Li-O2 batteries with the as-prepared cathode indicated an outstanding specific capacity of 23413 mA h g−1 under a high current of 1 A g−1, and extremely stable electrochemical reversibility with 193 loops at 1 A g−1 under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g-−1 [264]. In addition, Huang et al. certified the Li2O2 thin films with the assistance of NiFeO x nanofiber catalysts can significantly improve the electrochemical performance of Li-O2 batteries through experiments and first-principles calculations, which produced an initial discharge capacity of 16987 mA h gc −1 at current densities of 500 mA gc −1, and retained respectable cyclic stability of 126 cycles at 200 mA gc −1 with a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h gc −1. This outstanding performance could be ascribed to the strong support of Li 2a vacancies, small grains, and large contact area with the electrode/electrolyte under LiO2-rich conditions [265]. Based on the research on the catalytic performance of different bimetallic oxides in Li-O2 batteries, NiCo2O4, with its unique porous structure to provide a larger reaction surface area for accommodating Li2O2 and offering more electrocatalytic sites, enhances battery performance. MnCO2O4-graphene hybrid materials perform exceptionally well in Li-O2 batteries due to enhanced electron transfer capabilities and the three-dimensional structure NiFeO cubic spinel catalysts exhibit high capacitance and excellent stability at high current (1 A g−1) has the most potential for practical applications in Li-O2 batteries. To achieve higher battery energy density and longer cycle life, exploration of combinations of bimetallic oxides with other nanomaterials and carriers can be pursued. 3.3.7 Comparison of non-noble transition metal and metal oxides While the performance of non-noble metals and metal oxides may not surpass that of precious metals, with proper design, the performance of Li-O2 batteries has also seen significant improvement. As previously described, carbon-based substrates are suitable for Li-O2 batteries due to their high electronic conductivity, low cost, and ease of preparing porous structures. However, carbon can undergo side reactions with Li2O2, primarily leading to the formation of Li2CO3, which can impact battery performance. By introducing non-noble metal-based catalysts, it is not only possible to prevent non-noble metal catalyst aggregation and influence their performance, but it may also lead to synergistic effects. After the introduction of 3D graphene with Co/CoO, Li2O2 growth occurs on the surface of Co/CoO rather than on the carbon surface. This suggests that by reducing the carbon/Li2O2 interface during the electrochemical process, side reactions are alleviated, resulting in a significant improvement in the cyclic performance of the battery. Therefore, when introducing carbon materials, it is essential to consider side reactions more comprehensively. Moreover, there are various ways to improve the performance of catalysts even without the introduction of carbon materials. For example, Co3O4 nanosheets have been shown to enhance the performance of Li-O2 batteries by exposing more metal atoms, especially on the edge-enriched {111} surface, providing ample space for breaking chemical bonds and enhancing reaction activity, thus reducing overpotential, increasing discharge capacity, and extending cycle life. The α-MnO2 with a hollandite structure has been designed into nanowires and 3D layered frameworks, resulting in significant improvements in Li-O2 battery performance, including high discharge capacity, low overpotential, and extended cycle life. The use of metal oxide-graphene hybrids has demonstrated strong covalent coupling and efficient electron transfer, promoting catalytic reactions and enhancing battery performance. Fe2O3 and TiO2, due to their semiconductor properties, can greatly reduce battery overpotential when applied in photo-supported Li-O2 batteries, but their catalytic performance is relatively poorer compared to Co3O4 and α-MnO2. Fe metal is prone to oxidation, but when designed into Fe/N/C materials, it exhibits excellent catalytic performance and can effectively suppress side reactions, improving battery stability. In addition, the design of binary metal oxides is also a crucial approach that cannot be ignored, and they exhibit more superior electrochemical performance compared to single-metal oxides. Overall, the choice of metal oxide catalysts plays a crucial role in determining the electrocatalytic performance and stability of Li-O2 batteries, and various strategies have been explored to tailor the performance of these catalysts to enhance energy storage and cycling capabilities. 3.3.8 Metal carbide/nitride/sulfide/selenide materials 3.3.8.1 Metal carbides Metal carbides have the advantages of impressive conductivity, marvelous stability, and superior ORR activity than carbon, so they received much attention. For example, Yang et al. fabricated super thin TiC skin on multi-walled carbon nanotubes framework (MWNTs) and compared the catalytic activity of TiC/MWNTs, pure TiC, and MWNTs towards the discharge and charge reactions. The battery with TiC/MWNTs achieved a distinguished inferior overpotential of 0.49 V, a higher initial discharge capacity of 3842 mA h g−1 at 250 mA g−1, and long-period stability of 90 cycles with a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 250 mA g−1 after loading the catalyst of Ru nanoparticles [266]. The titanium carbide catalyst was further optimized to expand the active sites of Mxenes in catalytic applications for boosting the round-trip efficiency and reducing parasitic reactions in LOBs. Wang et al. prepared an ORR/OER bifunctional catalyst by anchoring Ti3C2 Mxene quantum dot clusters with rich crystal defects on N-doped carbon nanosheets (Ti3C2 QDC/N-C), it was found that the grain boundary and edge defects could regulate the local unsaturated coordination state of active titanium atoms and the electronic structure of Ti3C2 QDC/N-C, which was capable to promote the catalytic activity. Consequently, the constructed battery exhibited a remarkable specific capacity of 166022 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, long-term stability of 240 cycles at 200 mA g−1 with an brilliant discharge/charge overpotential of 0.62 V [267]. Titanium carbide (TiC) is designed to serve as the cathode of the battery, exhibiting remarkable conductivity, high capacity, and stability, thus holding great potential for metal carbides. 3.3.8.2 Metal nitrate Since the electronic energy level of N 2p orbitals in nitride materials is higher than that of O 2p orbitals, N-doped metal oxides can have high electronic conductivity by reducing the band gap or the overlap of conduction and valence bands. So far, various nitride materials including titanium nitride, molybdenum nitride, nickel nitride, cobalt nitride and nickel-iron nitride, and cobalt-molybdenum nitride have been explored for energy conversion and storage devices. Mu et al. compared the catalytic performance and electronic structure of two-dimensional molybdenum-based material catalysts (MoN, MoO3, and MoS). The results manifested that the MoN electrode possessed the highest discharge capacity of ∼7400 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 with the lowest overpotential of 0.91 V. DFT calculations suggested that MoN has metallic properties and therefore better conductivity. In addition, the robust MoO x layer formed on the MoN surface ensured stable cycling performance [188]. Yoon et al. synthesized brush-like Co4N nanorods uniformly immobilized on conductive electrospun CNF paper (Co4N/CNF) as a cathode for Li-O2 batteries. The battery performed a notable cycle life of over 177 cycles at 200 mA g−1 with a cut-off capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 as well as a low overpotential of ∼1.23 V at 700 mA h g−1. Furthermore, the pouch Li-air batteries using Co4N/CNF cathode operated stably in a real air environment even at 180° bending. The good performance was explained by direct electrical contact between the metallic catalyst and N-doped CNF, eliminating the need for binders, numerous active sites on the densely packed Co4N nanorods capable of accommodating solid reaction products, and the presence of a reliable and thin oxide layer (amorphous CoO x film) on Co4N, facilitating both the reversible formation/decomposition of Li2O2 film type [268]. In light of the electronic properties, electrochemical stability and catalytic activity of nitride materials such as MoN and Co4N, it is evident that they hold immense promise in energy conversion and storage applications. 3.3.8.3 Metal sulfides and selenide Metal sulfides have two advantages. Firstly, metal sulfides are usually inherently unstable, and various crystal defects will be formed during the formation process, which are conducive to the generation of rich active sites. Secondly, the valence states of various metal cations could facilitate the catalytic reactions [269,270]. The fast transport of ions and electrons accelerated by the built-in electric field, the multiple active sites of the heterostructure, and the nanotube structure with a large specific surface area ensure excellent electrochemical performance. Xia et al. produced MnCo2S4-CoS1.097 nanotubes via a reflux hydrothermal method. In this system, the MnCo2S4-CoS1.097 cathode performed a considerable discharge specific capacity of 21765 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1. It also exhibited good cyclability with a limited specific capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 1000 mA g−1 (167 cycles) and 2000 mA g−1 (57 cycles) [190]. Different from the above designs, Lin et al. synthesized an open-structured Co9S8 cathode with sisal morphology. By changing the morphology of Li2O2, the contact interface with the cathode was promoted, thereby realizing a good oxygen evolution process and promising Li2O2 storage matrix. The battery fabricated with Co9S8 cathode achieved an initial discharge capacity of ∼6875 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1 with a lower polarization of ∼0.86 V, and long-term life of 105 loops with a fixed specific capacity of 500 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 [269]. Except for CoS x materials, Chou's team reported that the defective MoS2 nanosheets were uniformly coated on the 3D carbon nanotube (CNT) network (Fig. 29 a and b). Firstly, the charge redistribution on the MoS2 nanosheets with sulfur vacancies was effectively constructed (Fig. 29c). Secondly, the conductive and high specific surface area CNT network could enhance mass transfer and provide sufficient free space for the composite cathode. More notably, the unique core-shell structure avoids the contact between the carbon nanotubes and the electrolyte, in addition, suppresses the occurrence of side reactions. The catalyst produced a remarkable discharge specific capacity of 19989 mA h g−1 with overpotentials of 0.99/0.26 V at 200 mA g−1 along with excellent electrochemical reversibility with 355 cycles under a cut-off specific capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 (Fig. 29d) [271]. Simultaneously, Li et al. coupled MoS2 and CoS2, which synergistically possessed a larger initial specific capacity of 10495 mA h g−1 (100 mA g−1) and longer lifespan of 120 cycles (200 mA g−1, 1000 mA h g−1) compared to the electrochemical performance of MoS2, CoS2, and KB [270]. Hu et al. investigated the composite NiS2/ZnIn2S4 with heterostructure, which delivered a high specific capacity of 3682 mA h g−1 at a current of 500 mA g−1 and outstanding cyclic stability up to 490 cycles at 500 mA g−1 with a confined capacity of 500 mA h g−1 (Fig. 29e and f). This performance was attributed to the fact that NiS2/ZnIn2S4 contributed to the interfacial electron transfer, modulates the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediates, and accelerates the O–O bond breaking, and finally realizes the toroid discharge product Li2O2 in the low DN solvent (Fig. 29g–i) [272]. In order to solve the problems of low intrinsic catalytic activity and heavy block of 2D MoS2, Zhang et al. prepared a three-dimensional metastable MoSSe solid solution (3D M-MoSSe) with high-degree local lattice distortion. The rapid diffusion of Li+ in the whole 3D metastable structure was confirmed via in situ TEM analysis. The battery based on the metastable 3D M-MoSSe achieved an initial specific capacity of ∼730 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1 with a low overpotential of 0.66 V over 30 cycles [273]. On the other hand, the core-shell nanostructured MoSe2@CNT adopting a uniform MoSe2 coating was reported by He et al., in which the continuous and multi-walled MoSe2 layers can not only induce the initial nucleation and growth of equiaxed Li2O2 grains on the cathode surface but also effectively prevent the by-products formed from corrosion between carbon and electrolyte. Consequently, the system performed a considerable specific capacity of over 32000 mA h g−1 (100 mA g−1), and superb cyclability of 280 cycles (500 mA g−1, 1000 mA h g−1) [274]. In summary, metal sulfides and metal selenides hold significant promise for enhancing performance in Li-O2 batteries. Metal sulfides represented by NiS2 provide impressive cyclic stability by modulating the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates and accelerating O–O bond breaking. On the other hand, metal selenides, like MoSe2, when incorporated into innovative structures, enable efficient discharge product formation and prevent the generation of harmful by-products. 3.3.8.4 Comparison of metal carbides/nitrates/sulfides/selenides In order to drive the advancement of energy storage technology, a variety of metal-based materials have emerged as promising candidates to enhance the performance of Li-O2 batteries. Metal carbides have stood out due to their outstanding conductivity, stability, and superior ORR activity compared to carbon. Incorporating Ti3C2 into a carbon nanotube framework has improved catalytic activity, reduced overpotential, and enhanced stability. Metal nitrides such as MoN and Co4N exhibit electronic characteristics, stability, and conductivity, with MoN in particular demonstrating metal-like properties that can enhance Li-O2 batteries efficiency. Metal sulfides and selenides, including MnCo2S4-CoS1.097, MoS2, and MoSe2, provide abundant active sites owing to crystal defects and favorable valence states, resulting in high discharge capacities. These materials, after innovative design and optimization, have all shown high discharge capacities and excellent cycling performance. Among them, metal sulfides exhibit the most remarkable cyclic performance, offering substantial promise for future energy storage solutions. Furthermore, these metal-based materials, including carbides, nitrides, sulfides, and selenides, still require further research and optimization to fully harness their potential in enhancing the performance of Li-O2 batteries. For example, through co-doping methods, there is hope that nitrogen doping of metal sulfides can generate synergistic effects, enhancing their conductivity and further improving their electrochemical performance. While they may not be able to completely replace precious metals in all scenarios, they provide a more cost-effective and sustainable alternative. 3.4 Emerging materials 3.4.1 Piezo-materials To enhance the reaction kinetics of the ORR and OER, numerous approaches have been designed, and recently, an innovative and effective method has been reported. Piezoelectric materials, which possess non-centrosymmetric structures allowing for the separation of positive and negative charge centers through mechanical deformation or an applied electric field, have emerged as a promising strategy. Zheng et al. introduced BaTiO3 (BTO) Piezo-catalysts into rechargeable Li-O2 battery systems to improve reaction kinetics and Li+ interface transport by harnessing intrinsic stress and the piezoelectric effect. This approach leverages the intrinsic stress generated during the growth and decomposition of Li2O2 to induce an intrinsic electric field, thus promoting ORR and OER kinetics while enhancing Li + transport. The piezoelectric effect leads to the generation of an internal electric field within BTO, which continuously separates and accumulates electrons and holes, guiding them to different surfaces for ORR to enhance the reaction rate. In-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and relaxation time distribution analysis reveal the relationship between the intrinsic stress-induced internal electric field and electrode kinetics, resulting in significant improvements in electron transfer and Li+ diffusion. As a result, compared to a carbon nanotube (CNT) cathode, the battery with a BTO-CNT cathode exhibited a lower overpotential of 0.65 V and a significantly higher capacity of 18,438 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1, while maintaining stability for 1800 hours under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 at 200 mA g−1 [275]. 3.4.2 High-entropy alloys High-entropy alloys (HEAs) composed of four or more metals with similar atomic ratios have shown immense potential in the field of catalysis due to their unexpected properties, including lattice distortion effects, slow diffusion effects, and synergistic effects [276]. The combinations of elements grant HEAs distinct electronic structures and active sites, making them suitable for electrocatalysis and nonaqueous batteries. The synergistic effects and interactions of different metal elements can significantly optimize interfacial electron transfer and adsorption energy for intermediates, thereby reducing the redox energy barriers [277]. Alloying precious metals with cost-effective transition metals has been shown to enhance catalytic activity and stability through strain and coordination effects [278]. Zhang et al. emphasized the importance of constructing heterojunctions combined with high-entropy alloy phases, creating a HEAs spatial heterostructure electrocatalyst (HEA@Pt). The unique heterointerfaces provided abundant active sites and modified the d-band centers of interface metal elements through DFT calculations, effectively adjusting the adsorption energy of oxygen species and accelerating ORR/OER reaction kinetics. The HEA@Pt-based battery achieved a low overpotential of 0.37 V and an ultra-long cycle life of 210 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1 with a fixed capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 [279]. The relationship between d-band centers and catalytic behavior is closely linked, and a set of catalysts with widely distributed d-band centers is needed to deepen this understanding. Tian et al. demonstrated, through a high-entropy strategy, that 3d transition metals with abundant unoccupied orbitals and high d-band centers exhibit negligible catalytic activity in Li-O2 batteries due to their high binding strength. As shown in Fig. 30 (a and b), when high electronegativity elements (e.g., Pt and Ir) serve as electron donors, they can continuously weaken the binding strength of these low d-band centers. The FeCoNiMnPtIr alloy achieved over 80% ultra-high energy conversion efficiency and a cycle time of 2000 h at 200 mA g−1 with a fixed capacity of 4000 mA h g−1 (Fig. 30c) [280]. In contrast to previous reports on HEAs focusing on optimizing catalytic performance by adjusting the chemical composition to induce lattice distortion effects and synergistic effects, Tao et al. concentrated on structural engineering, particularly in terms of dimension and size control. They used silver nanowires (NWs) as templates to prepare sub-nanometer 2D HEAs sub-nanoribbons (SNRs) as thin as 0.8 nm, composed of up to eight different metal elements. The battery exhibited outstanding performance with a low charge overpotential of 0.49 V and cycling stability of 100 cycles at 0.50 A g−1 under a limited capacity of 1000 mA h g−1. DFT results revealed that the concentration of highly dynamic reduction elements (Pd, Pt, Ag, abd Au) is crucial for achieving excellent electroactivity in HEAs, while relatively inert oxidative elements (Ir, Ru, Rh, and Os) promote inter-site electron transfer efficiency but may lead to local aggregation [277]. HEAs offer significant flexibility in the design of multi-element alloys, and such diversity also demonstrates their application potential. By adjusting alloy composition to modulate d-band centers and designing suitable structures to induce lattice distortion effects and synergistic effects, HEAs' catalytic effects can be enhanced. Additionally, structural engineering is an indispensable approach to obtaining electrocatalysts with large specific surface areas and abundant active sites. 3.4.3 Redox mediators In the traditional use of solid catalysts, during the charging reaction, charge transfer is expected to occur within the insulating medium of Li2O2 [98,118]. This often leads to significant kinetic limitations, resulting in a higher overpotential [193]. Researchers have shown interest in using redox mediators (RMs) as soluble catalysts. When RMs are employed, they serve as mobile charge carriers in the electrolyte. During the charging process, RMs are oxidized at the electrode surface to form RM+, and they can subsequently diffuse into the electrolyte, where they oxidize solid Li2O2, leading to the release of oxygen and the regeneration of RM [44]. This significantly reduces the charging potential during the cycling process. The reduced charging potential not only enhances energy efficiency but also promotes the battery's durability. The operational mechanism of RMs in the charging process can be described as follows (Fig. 31 ). Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) was initially employed as an organic RM in Li-O2 batteries by Bruce's team [44]. By dissolving it in the electrolyte, it enables highly efficient oxidation reactions on the electrode surface. TTF undergoes oxidation at the anode surface, forming TTF+. Subsequently, TTF+ further oxidizes solid Li2O2 while simultaneously self-reducing to regenerate TTF. TTF plays a role as an electron-hole transport mediator in Li-O2 batteries, effectively facilitating the transfer of electrons and Li+ between the electrode surface and Li2O2 particles, thereby reducing the potential polarization required for the oxidation reaction of solid Li2O2. The introduction of TTF significantly improves the cycling performance of Li-O2 batteries, enabling up to 100 charge-discharge cycles. They also reported the use of 2,5-di-tert-butyl-1,4-benzoquinone (DBBQ) as a redox mediator in the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [281]. Unlike other RMs, DBBQ has a distinctive role in influencing the ORR. It effectively stabilizes lithium ions in the solution, thereby aiding in the formation of stable LiO2 − ions in the solution. This situation promotes the formation of large Li2O2 deposits through a top-down mechanism. Furthermore, they have demonstrated the synergistic effect of using both ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) mediators [282]. They presented a battery that simultaneously incorporates DBBQ and TEMPO as discharge and charge mediators, as shown in Fig. 32 . This dual redox mediator battery does not involve any direct oxygen redox chemistry on the electrode surface, significantly suppressing parasitic reactions and enhancing cycling stability. Using this approach, Li-O2 batteries can achieve 2 mA h cm−2 areal at high areal current density (1 mA cm−2 areal) with low polarization. Based on the above findings, it is evident that RMs offer a viable approach to achieving high efficiency and long cycling in Li-O2 batteries. Askins et al. conducted research on a novel redox mediator for Li-O2 batteries based on a triarylmethyl cation motifs [283]. They utilized computational and experimental methods to explore inner-sphere and outer-sphere mechanisms and found that only the outer-sphere mechanism could effectively close the catalytic cycle. These triarylmethyl cations exhibited significant catalytic activity, especially those with larger negative reduction potentials, leading to a remarkable up to 35-fold increase in Li-O2 discharge capacity. Surprisingly, “sluggish” mediators with more positive reduction potentials achieved even larger capacities because they effectively suppressed surface-mediated O2 reduction. Moreover, the research demonstrated that redox mediation could be achieved even for mediators with more positive reduction potentials through operating at high concentrations. Unlike the past where most discharge mediators are quinone-based, this work introduces a promising class of RMs, providing valuable insights for the design of future mediators. Despite the numerous advantages of RMs, they also introduce potential instability to batteries. Firstly, RMs can potentially reach the reactive lithium metal anode due to their mobile nature. This phenomenon is referred to as “redox shuttle” and leads to self-discharge through irreversible reactions with the lithium metal [284]. To address these issues, the lithium metal surface needs to be protected by the formation of an artificial solid electrolyte interface (SEI). Additionally, for RMs to exhibit activity in the decomposition of Li2O2, their redox potentials should be close to E 0(O2/Li2O2) = 2.96 V vs. Li+/Li while maintaining a high mediating activity. Lim and colleagues conducted research on representative organic RMs to identify the key factors that determine their catalytic activity and electrochemical stability in solvents [285]. The research results demonstrated that RMs with their oxidized forms having singly occupied molecular orbitals (SOMO) close to the solvent's highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) are prone to extracting electrons from the solvent and decomposing it. These findings provide critical guidance for designing more effective RMs, which in turn contributes to enhancing battery performance. 4 Conclusions and perspectives In this comprehensive review, we made a special report on the latest progress on the oxygen electrode of high energy density non-aqueous Li-O2 batteries, focusing on the rational design of oxygen electrode materials, including well-defined porous structure, the introduction of dopants, and manufacturing defects or heterojunctions, which can be used not only as a highly active oxygen electrocatalyst to improve the slow ORR and OER but also as a conductive porous oxygen electrode to promote the transfer of electrons and mass. Such electrode materials should provide sufficient accommodation space for the discharge products as well as a key function for inducing the evolution of Li2O2 clusters. In addition, to improve the sustainability of Li-O2 batteries, careful evaluation of the cathode itself and the stability of the cathode to electrochemically oxidized organic electrolytes are required. Attempts are made to elucidate the discharge/charge mechanism of Li-O2 batteries. According to the current achievements, the reasonable functional design of the structure, composition, and surface performance of candidate materials play a significant role in improving the energy density, round-trip efficiency, speed capacity, cycle stability, safety, and flexibility of Li-O2 batteries. However, more efforts and some research directions are needed to give full play to the potential of oxygen electrodes in Li-O2 batteries. First of all, exploring highly active cathode materials with large storage capacity is the key to building high-performance Li-O2 batteries. It predominantly involves the following two aspects: On one hand, building a porous or hierarchical porous structure with a high specific surface area and large pore volume to provide multiple channels for electrons, oxygen, and Li+, and storage space for discharge products, which is capable of solving many key problems of Li-O2 batteries, including large overpotential during charge and discharge, electrode corrosion and decomposition and volatilization of electrolyte. When designing porous carbon materials, drawing inspiration from the generalized Murray's law offers a highly promising approach. The generalized Murray's law, which guides the design of hierarchical porous networks like natural organisms, minimizes transport resistance for all pores, ensuring smooth transfer throughout the network [286–289]. By incorporating the generalized Murray's law into the design of synthetic carbon materials with multi-scale pores, the potential for achieving outstanding structural advantages and performance enhancements has been realized, such as lithium-selenium batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries [290–294]. Therefore, it is highly suitable for rapid transport of electrons, O2, and Li+ and Li2O2 storage in Li-O2 batteries. On the other hand introducing dopants, defects, and other active phases to improve the catalytic activity of ORR and OER; In particular, graphene-based materials reveal high capacity by coupling with various active materials [92]. In addition, for CNT-based materials, the unique core-shell structure avoids direct contact between CNT and electrolyte and effectively inhibits the occurrence of side reactions. The rational design and controllable manufacturing method of heterostructures that combine the synergistic advantages of two different nanosheets, single/diatomic catalysts, or nanoalloys supported on 2D materials cannot be ignored [230]. It maximizes the performance of ORR/OER in the cathode, thereby effectively improving the discharge/charge capacity, round-trip efficiency, rate performance, and cycle stability. Secondly, precious metal catalysts have demonstrated significant advantages in Li-O2 batteries, including outstanding catalytic performance and rapid reaction kinetics. Among them, both Au and Ru exhibit excellent properties for suppressing side reactions. The strong interaction between RuO2 and Li2O2 when distributed on CNTs can enhance the conductivity of insulating Li2O2. Embedding Li2O nanoparticles into Ir/rGO enables the development of a Li-O2 battery system with reversible Li2O/Li2O2 conversion in the absence of O2, resulting in remarkable stability. However, the high cost and scarcity of precious metals necessitate further research and improvement, including strategies like alloying, incorporating porous structures, and interface engineering, to overcome cost and resource limitations. Additionally, the development of efficient non-precious metal catalysts is a potential strategy to address these challenges. Among non-precious metals, α-MnO2 with a hollandite structure offers significant potential due to its ability to accommodate Li+ and O2 − ions within its tunnels, even Li+ and O2 2−, showing great promise for Li-O2 batteries performance. The utilization of Fe2O3 and TiO2, owing to their semiconductor properties, can enhance Li-O2 batteries by mitigating the high energy barrier and overpotential through photo-assisted processes. In order to face the application of Li-O2 batteries at a high current, NiFeO cubic spine exhibits excellent performance. Non-precious metal-based materials, including carbides, nitrides, sulfides, and selenides, outperform metal oxides, especially metal sulfides, which hold the potential for replacing precious metals. The new conceptual catalyst, high-entropy alloys composed of multiple elements, brings significant flexibility and potential to the design of electrocatalysts. Therefore, there is a need for further methods to enhance their performance, such as structural design and preparation optimization to precisely control crystal structures, morphologies, and surface atomic arrangements, as well as interface engineering to reduce resistance within the battery and enhance energy transfer efficiency. In addition, the use of redox mediators in Li-O2 batteries significantly reduces the charging potential during the cycling process. However, they come with potential instability issues such as redox shuttle, which can impact the cycling performance of the batteries. Therefore, as a relatively new field, this area requires a combination of computational approaches, advanced characterization techniques, and further innovative and systematic work to address these challenges. Thirdly, although the current design of advanced materials and structures can effectively promote and maintain the electrochemical reaction of anode and cathode, it is demanding to realize the rapid and sustainable reaction of Li-O2 batteries. For example, one of the biggest challenges faced by Li-O2 batteries is their rate capability, that is, the equipment ought to work at a high current rate. Recent studies have only focused on studies at relatively low current rates (below 1 A g−1). At high current rates, the efficiency of mass transport and electron transport, including Li+ transport through the interface and electrolyte, O2 transport to the two-phase/three-phase interface, and electron transport between the electrode and O2/Li2O2, strongly affects the formation and decomposition rate of Li2O2. Therefore, when constructing practical Li-O2 batteries, it is very important to have a deep understanding of the battery mechanism. In particular, investigating the role of active centers in the catalytic reaction of interfacial interaction contributes to reasonably designing functional materials of Li-O2 batteries with activity, selectivity and stability to realize the construction of battery systems with high specific energy, high rate, and long cycle life. Another side reaction that needs to be noticed is that Li+ based by-products (LiOH and Li2CO3) are usually challenging to decompose due to their high equilibrium potential, which can lead to cathode pore blockage and sudden death of the battery. Therefore, the charge and discharge process of the battery should be fully considered and systematically optimized. Understanding the exact evolution mechanism of the formation and decomposition of discharge products and other by-products will help to realize the high stability of the Li-O2 batteries. Lastly, it is necessary to reasonably use a variety of advanced characterization techniques and theoretical model calculations to determine the evolution of the structure during the charge and discharge process and clarify the reaction process and reaction mechanism. In addition, some new in-situ characterization technologies, such as extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and electron spin resonance (ESR) are expected to study the detailed valence state information of catalysts, O2, and related reaction intermediates [34,48]. In situ Raman spectroscopy has been used to detect the effects of reaction intermediates and solvents in Li-O2 batteries [192]. These findings could be valuable for further exploring the performance of batteries under different conditions.
